weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive auditing and monitoring of all API calls and actions made through AWS API Gateway, configure AWS CloudTrail to record these activities. This setup is critical for maintaining a transparent and secure environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Enable AWS CloudTrail: Make sure AWS CloudTrail is enabled in your AWS account. CloudTrail records all API calls made to AWS services, including API Gateway, and stores the log files in an S3 bucket.
    AWS CloudTrail Documentation
  2. Create a Trail: Create a trail to capture all API Gateway calls. A trail configuration allows you to capture management and data events for API Gateway resources.
    Creating a CloudTrail Trail
  3. Configure Logging for API Gateway: Ensure that API Gateway logging is enabled. You can configure it in the API Gateway console under the logging settings for each API stage.
    Setting up CloudWatch API Logging for API Gateway
  4. Verify Logging and Monitoring: Consistently monitor the logs produced in CloudTrail and CloudWatch. This proactive measure will help in early detection of any unauthorized or suspicious activities.
    AWS Security Hub Recommended Standards

By following these steps, you will enhance the visibility and security of your AWS API Gateway environment, ensuring that all activities are recorded and monitored effectively.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure compliance and detect unauthorized changes in your AWS API Gateway resources, use AWS Config to continuously monitor and evaluate their configurations. AWS Config provides a detailed view of the AWS resource configurations, their relationships, and changes over time.

Heres a step-by-step guide for cloud engineers to implement this control:

  1. Enable AWS Config in your AWS account. Follow the documentation to set up AWS Config by defining an IAM role with the necessary permissions, specifying an S3 bucket to store configuration snapshots, and selecting the AWS resources you want to monitor.
  2. Create a Config Rule to evaluate the configuration of your API Gateway resources. AWS Config provides a set of managed rules, or you can create custom rules using AWS Lambda. For API Gateway, you might use the AWS-managed rule called "api-gateway-gateway-response-check", which checks for best practices and compliance.
  3. Use the AWS Config console or CLI to associate the rules with the API Gateway resources. Define the compliance criteria that the rule will evaluate, such as specific security configurations or limits.
  4. Set up notifications for non-compliance using Amazon SNS. This can help in alerting teams instantaneously if there are unauthorized changes or misconfigurations detected.
  5. Regularly review the compliance status and history of changes in the AWS Config dashboard to maintain best practices and ensure security measures are consistently applied.

Refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices for more details on maintaining a secure configuration for your API Gateway resources.

countermeasure.name: Implement Amazon CloudWatch alarms
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure robust security monitoring of your API Gateway, it's critical to leverage Amazon CloudWatch metrics and alarms. This proactive measure will aid in the prompt detection and response to any anomalies or potential security issues.

Begin by accessing the Amazon CloudWatch console within AWS Management Console. Navigate to the "Metrics" section to ensure you are monitoring the relevant metrics for API Gateway. Key metrics to focus on include:

  • 4XXError: Counts the number of client-side errors (useful for detecting potential abuse).
  • 5XXError: Counts the number of server-side errors (indicates the health of the backend or integration).
  • Count: Number of API requests received (to identify unusual spikes in traffic).
  • Latency: Measures the time taken from the API Gateway receiving a request until it responds (to detect performance degradation).

After identifying these metrics, set up CloudWatch Alarms to notify your security team when any of the thresholds are breached. To do this:

  1. In the CloudWatch console, go to "Alarms" and click on "Create Alarm".
  2. Select the API Gateway metric you want to monitor, such as 4XXError or 5XXError.
  3. Define the appropriate thresholds based on your security policy. For instance, configure an alarm to trigger if the 5XXError exceeds a specific number within a predetermined timeframe.
  4. Set up notification actions, such as sending an alert to an AWS SNS topic, which will forward the notification to the relevant personnel via email or SMS.
  5. Optionally, automate responses using AWS Lambda functions to handle detected anomalies, like throttling suspicious IPs or alerting a security operations center (SOC).

Additionally, ensure compliance with security best practices by reviewing the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation regularly.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure that resources within AWS API Gateway are only accessible by authorized entities, it is pivotal to utilize IAM policies that adhere to the principle of least privilege. This approach minimizes the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches. Implementing this countermeasure involves creating precise and restrictive IAM policies that grant the minimum necessary permissions required for users or roles to perform their functions.

Follow these steps to implement IAM policies based on the principle of least privilege:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the exact permissions needed by each user, role, or service account to interact with AWS API Gateway. Avoid granting broad permissions that are not necessary.
  2. Create Custom IAM Policies: Write custom IAM policies that define granular permissions. Use specific actions (e.g., `apigateway:GET`, `apigateway:POST`) and restrict access to the necessary resources (e.g., specific API IDs or stages).
  3. Apply the Policies: Attach the custom IAM policies to the relevant IAM users, groups, or roles. Ensure that the policies are evaluated and tested to confirm they provide the intended access without excess permissions.
  4. Enable Policy Versioning and Logging: Maintain policy versioning to keep track of changes and use AWS CloudTrail for monitoring and logging API Gateway access activity, which helps in auditing and compliance.
  5. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review the permissions and update IAM policies as needed to adapt to any changes in requirements or security posture.

For more detailed information and best practices on securing your API Gateway using IAM policies, refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Implement logging
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure visibility and traceability of all activities occurring in your AWS API Gateway, it is essential to implement monitoring and logging mechanisms using Amazon CloudWatch Logs or Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. This practice aligns with the security guidelines as specified in the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable API Gateway Execution Logging: Access the API Gateway in the AWS Management Console and navigate to the stage settings. Under the Logs/Tracing tab, enable Access Logging and specify the CloudWatch Logs group. Follow the detailed instructions in the API Gateway Logging Setup Guide.
  2. Set up CloudWatch Logs: If using CloudWatch Logs, ensure that the necessary IAM roles and permissions are in place to allow API Gateway to write logs. Configure log retention policies according to your organizational compliance requirements.
  3. Implement Kinesis Data Firehose: If opting for Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose, create a delivery stream to capture the logs and optionally transform and load them into destination services such as Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift, or Amazon Elasticsearch Service. For integration, refer to Creating an Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose Delivery Stream.
  4. Review and Monitor Logs: Regularly review the logs to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts. Set up CloudWatch Alarms to alert your security team of any suspicious activities.
By adhering to these guidelines and leveraging CloudWatch Logs or Kinesis Data Firehose, you can enhance the security posture of your API Gateway by maintaining comprehensive visibility and traceability of API operations.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Security Hub
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Security Hub provides a comprehensive view of security alerts and compliance status across AWS accounts for API Gateway implementations. By integrating AWS Security Hub with your AWS API Gateway, you can effectively manage and monitor security risks and ensure adherence to best practices. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:
  1. Enable AWS Security Hub: Start by enabling AWS Security Hub in the AWS Management Console. Navigate to the Security Hub dashboard and select "Get Started." Ensure it's activated in the appropriate AWS region where your API Gateway resources are hosted.

    Reference: Setting Up AWS Security Hub

  2. Configure Findings and Insights: AWS Security Hub aggregates findings from various AWS services. Ensure that findings from AWS API Gateway are included. Inspect and prioritize these findings to understand the security and compliance status.

    Reference: Understanding Findings

  3. Enable Security Standards: Activate relevant security standards like the AWS Foundational Security Best Practices standard to receive automated checks for common security configurations and vulnerabilities in your API Gateway setup.

    Reference: AWS Foundational Security Best Practices

  4. Regularly Review and Act: Regularly review the insights and findings provided by Security Hub. Implement recommended actions, such as applying least privilege principles, enabling logging and monitoring, and ensuring proper API Gateway configuration as advised in the AWS API Gateway security best practices.

    Reference: API Gateway Security Best Practices

By systematically implementing these steps, you can ensure that your AWS API Gateway environments are securely managed and compliant with established security best practices.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured IAM policies can create vulnerabilities by allowing unauthorized users to access and manipulate API Gateway resources, leading to security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders who exploit weak or overly permissive IAM policies to gain access to API Gateway resources.
Impacts
Unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exposure of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies an IAM policy that grants overly broad permissions and uses it to access and modify API Gateway settings, potentially disrupting services or exfiltrating data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Non-compliance with security best practices
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failing to continuously monitor and adhere to security best practices can expose the system to vulnerabilities and lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include cyber attackers, malicious insiders, and even accidental misconfigurations. Attack vectors can be as diverse as exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities, pivoting through misconfigured services, and taking advantage of outdated security frameworks.
Impacts
The impacts may include data breaches, financial losses, legal penalties, damage to reputation, and disruption of business operations. Regulatory non-compliance can result in fines and restrictions on business activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A cyber attacker identifies unpatched vulnerabilities in the API Gateway and exploits them to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. 2. Due to lack of continuous monitoring, an internal user accidentally misconfigures security settings, exposing critical resources to the internet. 3. Failure to adhere to encryption best practices leads to data being transmitted in plaintext, which is intercepted by an attacker.

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Delayed threat detection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without continuous monitoring and alerting, security threats may go undetected for extended periods, increasing the likelihood of significant damage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors can exploit vulnerabilities in your AWS infrastructure that are not promptly identified due to inadequate monitoring and alerting systems. This includes issues like unpatched software, misconfigurations, and unauthorized access attempts.
Impacts
Delayed detection can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, data loss, and potentially significant downtime. There can also be financial repercussions, reputational damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to your AWS API Gateway due to a misconfiguration. Without monitoring, this unauthorized activity goes unnoticed, allowing the attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data over a prolonged period.
2. A vulnerability in an API is exploited, but because continuous monitoring is not in place, the breach is discovered only after considerable damage has been done.
3. An insider modifies configurations maliciously, leading to data leaks or system downtimes that are only detected after client complaints.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Unmonitored changes and activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper logging, unauthorized changes and activities can go unnoticed, leading to potential vulnerabilities and compliance issues.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal employees or external attackers making unauthorized changes, malicious activities occurring within the AWS environment.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, non-compliance with industry regulations, potential financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal employee alters API configurations without authorization, leading to data exposure. An attacker exploits an API vulnerability, and the lack of logging prevents early detection and response. Audits reveal insufficient logging, resulting in compliance fines.

threat.name: Lack of audit trails
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without audit trails, it is challenging to track changes and access patterns to API Gateway resources, increasing the risk of undetected security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers, internal malicious users, or even compromised legitimate users. Attack vectors can include unauthorized access, modification of API configurations, and attempts to exploit vulnerabilities in the API.
Impacts
The lack of audit trails can lead to severe impacts including data breaches, unauthorized access, unnoticed manipulation of sensitive information, and difficulties in incident response and forensic investigation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An external attacker gains access to API Gateway and modifies API configurations to exfiltrate sensitive data without detection. 2. An internal employee with malicious intent changes configurations and accesses sensitive customer data, remaining undetected due to the lack of audit trails. 3. A legitimate users account is compromised and used to exploit an API vulnerability, causing data leakage and operational disruptions without raising any alarms.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Configuration drift
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unmonitored configuration changes can lead to configuration drift, making the environment non-compliant with security policies and prone to vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel, accidental misconfigurations, or insider threats making untracked changes to the configuration settings.
Impacts
Breach of security policies, increased vulnerability to attacks, potential data breaches, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider makes a change to the API Gateway configuration that disables logging, making it difficult to detect malicious activities. Unknown to the security team, an attacker exploits the misconfigured resource, leading to a data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

countermeasure.name: Implement Amazon CloudWatch alarms
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure robust security monitoring of your API Gateway, it's critical to leverage Amazon CloudWatch metrics and alarms. This proactive measure will aid in the prompt detection and response to any anomalies or potential security issues.

Begin by accessing the Amazon CloudWatch console within AWS Management Console. Navigate to the "Metrics" section to ensure you are monitoring the relevant metrics for API Gateway. Key metrics to focus on include:

  • 4XXError: Counts the number of client-side errors (useful for detecting potential abuse).
  • 5XXError: Counts the number of server-side errors (indicates the health of the backend or integration).
  • Count: Number of API requests received (to identify unusual spikes in traffic).
  • Latency: Measures the time taken from the API Gateway receiving a request until it responds (to detect performance degradation).

After identifying these metrics, set up CloudWatch Alarms to notify your security team when any of the thresholds are breached. To do this:

  1. In the CloudWatch console, go to "Alarms" and click on "Create Alarm".
  2. Select the API Gateway metric you want to monitor, such as 4XXError or 5XXError.
  3. Define the appropriate thresholds based on your security policy. For instance, configure an alarm to trigger if the 5XXError exceeds a specific number within a predetermined timeframe.
  4. Set up notification actions, such as sending an alert to an AWS SNS topic, which will forward the notification to the relevant personnel via email or SMS.
  5. Optionally, automate responses using AWS Lambda functions to handle detected anomalies, like throttling suspicious IPs or alerting a security operations center (SOC).

Additionally, ensure compliance with security best practices by reviewing the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation regularly.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure that resources within AWS API Gateway are only accessible by authorized entities, it is pivotal to utilize IAM policies that adhere to the principle of least privilege. This approach minimizes the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches. Implementing this countermeasure involves creating precise and restrictive IAM policies that grant the minimum necessary permissions required for users or roles to perform their functions.

Follow these steps to implement IAM policies based on the principle of least privilege:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the exact permissions needed by each user, role, or service account to interact with AWS API Gateway. Avoid granting broad permissions that are not necessary.
  2. Create Custom IAM Policies: Write custom IAM policies that define granular permissions. Use specific actions (e.g., `apigateway:GET`, `apigateway:POST`) and restrict access to the necessary resources (e.g., specific API IDs or stages).
  3. Apply the Policies: Attach the custom IAM policies to the relevant IAM users, groups, or roles. Ensure that the policies are evaluated and tested to confirm they provide the intended access without excess permissions.
  4. Enable Policy Versioning and Logging: Maintain policy versioning to keep track of changes and use AWS CloudTrail for monitoring and logging API Gateway access activity, which helps in auditing and compliance.
  5. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review the permissions and update IAM policies as needed to adapt to any changes in requirements or security posture.

For more detailed information and best practices on securing your API Gateway using IAM policies, refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Implement logging
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure visibility and traceability of all activities occurring in your AWS API Gateway, it is essential to implement monitoring and logging mechanisms using Amazon CloudWatch Logs or Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. This practice aligns with the security guidelines as specified in the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable API Gateway Execution Logging: Access the API Gateway in the AWS Management Console and navigate to the stage settings. Under the Logs/Tracing tab, enable Access Logging and specify the CloudWatch Logs group. Follow the detailed instructions in the API Gateway Logging Setup Guide.
  2. Set up CloudWatch Logs: If using CloudWatch Logs, ensure that the necessary IAM roles and permissions are in place to allow API Gateway to write logs. Configure log retention policies according to your organizational compliance requirements.
  3. Implement Kinesis Data Firehose: If opting for Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose, create a delivery stream to capture the logs and optionally transform and load them into destination services such as Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift, or Amazon Elasticsearch Service. For integration, refer to Creating an Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose Delivery Stream.
  4. Review and Monitor Logs: Regularly review the logs to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts. Set up CloudWatch Alarms to alert your security team of any suspicious activities.
By adhering to these guidelines and leveraging CloudWatch Logs or Kinesis Data Firehose, you can enhance the security posture of your API Gateway by maintaining comprehensive visibility and traceability of API operations.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Security Hub
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Security Hub provides a comprehensive view of security alerts and compliance status across AWS accounts for API Gateway implementations. By integrating AWS Security Hub with your AWS API Gateway, you can effectively manage and monitor security risks and ensure adherence to best practices. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:
  1. Enable AWS Security Hub: Start by enabling AWS Security Hub in the AWS Management Console. Navigate to the Security Hub dashboard and select "Get Started." Ensure it's activated in the appropriate AWS region where your API Gateway resources are hosted.

    Reference: Setting Up AWS Security Hub

  2. Configure Findings and Insights: AWS Security Hub aggregates findings from various AWS services. Ensure that findings from AWS API Gateway are included. Inspect and prioritize these findings to understand the security and compliance status.

    Reference: Understanding Findings

  3. Enable Security Standards: Activate relevant security standards like the AWS Foundational Security Best Practices standard to receive automated checks for common security configurations and vulnerabilities in your API Gateway setup.

    Reference: AWS Foundational Security Best Practices

  4. Regularly Review and Act: Regularly review the insights and findings provided by Security Hub. Implement recommended actions, such as applying least privilege principles, enabling logging and monitoring, and ensuring proper API Gateway configuration as advised in the AWS API Gateway security best practices.

    Reference: API Gateway Security Best Practices

By systematically implementing these steps, you can ensure that your AWS API Gateway environments are securely managed and compliant with established security best practices.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured IAM policies can create vulnerabilities by allowing unauthorized users to access and manipulate API Gateway resources, leading to security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders who exploit weak or overly permissive IAM policies to gain access to API Gateway resources.
Impacts
Unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exposure of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies an IAM policy that grants overly broad permissions and uses it to access and modify API Gateway settings, potentially disrupting services or exfiltrating data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Non-compliance with security best practices
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failing to continuously monitor and adhere to security best practices can expose the system to vulnerabilities and lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include cyber attackers, malicious insiders, and even accidental misconfigurations. Attack vectors can be as diverse as exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities, pivoting through misconfigured services, and taking advantage of outdated security frameworks.
Impacts
The impacts may include data breaches, financial losses, legal penalties, damage to reputation, and disruption of business operations. Regulatory non-compliance can result in fines and restrictions on business activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A cyber attacker identifies unpatched vulnerabilities in the API Gateway and exploits them to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. 2. Due to lack of continuous monitoring, an internal user accidentally misconfigures security settings, exposing critical resources to the internet. 3. Failure to adhere to encryption best practices leads to data being transmitted in plaintext, which is intercepted by an attacker.

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Delayed threat detection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without continuous monitoring and alerting, security threats may go undetected for extended periods, increasing the likelihood of significant damage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors can exploit vulnerabilities in your AWS infrastructure that are not promptly identified due to inadequate monitoring and alerting systems. This includes issues like unpatched software, misconfigurations, and unauthorized access attempts.
Impacts
Delayed detection can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, data loss, and potentially significant downtime. There can also be financial repercussions, reputational damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to your AWS API Gateway due to a misconfiguration. Without monitoring, this unauthorized activity goes unnoticed, allowing the attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data over a prolonged period.
2. A vulnerability in an API is exploited, but because continuous monitoring is not in place, the breach is discovered only after considerable damage has been done.
3. An insider modifies configurations maliciously, leading to data leaks or system downtimes that are only detected after client complaints.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Unmonitored changes and activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper logging, unauthorized changes and activities can go unnoticed, leading to potential vulnerabilities and compliance issues.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal employees or external attackers making unauthorized changes, malicious activities occurring within the AWS environment.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, non-compliance with industry regulations, potential financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal employee alters API configurations without authorization, leading to data exposure. An attacker exploits an API vulnerability, and the lack of logging prevents early detection and response. Audits reveal insufficient logging, resulting in compliance fines.

threat.name: Lack of audit trails
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without audit trails, it is challenging to track changes and access patterns to API Gateway resources, increasing the risk of undetected security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers, internal malicious users, or even compromised legitimate users. Attack vectors can include unauthorized access, modification of API configurations, and attempts to exploit vulnerabilities in the API.
Impacts
The lack of audit trails can lead to severe impacts including data breaches, unauthorized access, unnoticed manipulation of sensitive information, and difficulties in incident response and forensic investigation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An external attacker gains access to API Gateway and modifies API configurations to exfiltrate sensitive data without detection. 2. An internal employee with malicious intent changes configurations and accesses sensitive customer data, remaining undetected due to the lack of audit trails. 3. A legitimate users account is compromised and used to exploit an API vulnerability, causing data leakage and operational disruptions without raising any alarms.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Configuration drift
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unmonitored configuration changes can lead to configuration drift, making the environment non-compliant with security policies and prone to vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel, accidental misconfigurations, or insider threats making untracked changes to the configuration settings.
Impacts
Breach of security policies, increased vulnerability to attacks, potential data breaches, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider makes a change to the API Gateway configuration that disables logging, making it difficult to detect malicious activities. Unknown to the security team, an attacker exploits the misconfigured resource, leading to a data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed flow logging
countermeasure.desc:
To activate detailed logging for all AWS AppFlow activities, enabling comprehensive monitoring and auditing, begin by integrating AWS CloudTrail with your AppFlow service. AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, role, or an AWS service in AppFlow, allowing you to track the full spectrum of activities and mitigate potential security risks.

Follow these steps to implement the control:

  1. Ensure that CloudTrail is enabled in all regions where AWS AppFlow is utilized. This facilitates a complete log collection.
  2. Go to the AWS CloudTrail console and create or verify the presence of a trail.
  3. When setting up or editing the trail, configure it to log all Management Events. This ensures that actions performed by AWS AppFlow are captured.
  4. Specify the destination S3 bucket to store your CloudTrail logs. Apply the necessary bucket policies to secure the logs.
  5. Enable CloudTrail log file integrity validation to ensure the log files have not been tampered with after delivery.
  6. Optionally, you can integrate the trail with AWS CloudWatch Logs to monitor specific AppFlow activities or AWS Athena for advanced querying and analysis.

Refer to the official AWS AppFlow CloudTrail Logging Documentation for detailed steps and additional best practices to implement this control effectively.

By activating detailed logging, you create a robust mechanism to perform auditing, forensic analysis, and ensure compliance with security policies.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption for data in transit and at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that data transmitted between AWS and SaaS applications via AWS AppFlow is encrypted both in transit and at rest, follow these steps:

Data Encryption in Transit

  • Use secure transport protocols such as HTTPS to encrypt data in transit. AWS AppFlow transfers data over HTTPS using TLS (Transport Layer Security) to provide end-to-end encryption.
  • Verify that the SaaS application supports HTTPS and is configured to use it by default.

Refer to the official documentation on Network Security for more details on secure data transmission.

Data Encryption at Rest

  • Ensure that data stored in your AWS services such as Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift, or Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) is encrypted at rest. AWS services provide the functionality to encrypt data at rest using AWS Key Management Service (KMS).
  • Configure AWS KMS for key management and designate appropriate policies to control access to these keys.
  • When setting up AWS AppFlow, make sure to specify the KMS key to use for encryption at rest when configuring the flow steps that involve data storage.

For additional guidance on data protection and encryption, see the Data Protection documentation.

By following these measures, you ensure that sensitive data is encrypted throughout its lifecycle, maintaining integrity and confidentiality. For comprehensive information on AWS AppFlow security practices, always refer to the official AWS AppFlow Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Review and validate data flow configurations
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly reviewing configuration settings for each data flow in AWS AppFlow is a crucial step to ensure that data is being transferred securely to approved destinations. To implement this control, follow these steps:

  1. Access the AWS Management Console: Log in to the AWS Management Console and navigate to the AWS AppFlow service.
  2. Review Existing Flows: Go to the Flows section and review the list of configured data flows. Ensure that every data flow is documented and associated with an approved destination.
  3. Check Flow Details: For each data flow, click to view the details. Verify the source and destination endpoints, authentication methods, and any applied data transformations. Ensure these conform to organizational security policies.
  4. Validate Connection Profiles: Confirm that the connection profiles used in your data flows are configured securely. Verify the credentials and permissions used are minimal and suitable for the required operations.
  5. Use IAM Policies: Ensure AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies are tightly controlled. Review and update policies to ensure that only authorized users can create, modify, or access data flows. Refer to the role-based access control guidelines for more information.
  6. Audit Logs: Enable and review audit logging for AWS AppFlow. Use AWS CloudTrail to monitor and log API calls and actions to ensure compliance and detect unauthorized changes. See the troubleshooting access and logging guidance for details.
  7. Regular Schedule: Establish a regular review schedule (e.g., monthly or quarterly) to re-evaluate and ensure compliance with approved configurations. Document the review process and findings for accountability.

By following these guidelines and leveraging AWS AppFlows security features, you can ensure that your data flows are properly secured and aligned with organizational policies.

countermeasure.name: Use restrictive IAM permissions
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS AppFlow resources, apply IAM policies that strictly control access to these resources. Implementing this countermeasure ensures that only authorized users and applications have the necessary permissions to interact with AppFlow. Follow these steps to implement such policies:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the specific AWS AppFlow actions your users or applications need to perform. These could include actions like appflow:CreateFlow, appflow:ListFlows, and appflow:RunFlow.
  2. Create a Custom IAM Policy: Using the principle of least privilege, create a custom IAM policy that grants only the permissions identified in the previous step. Below is an example of a custom policy JSON: 
        
    {
        "Version": "2012-10-17",
        "Statement": [
            {
                "Effect": "Allow",
                "Action": [
                    "appflow:CreateFlow",
                    "appflow:ListFlows",
                    "appflow:DescribeFlow",
                    "appflow:RunFlow"
                ],
                "Resource": [
                    "arn:aws:appflow:region:account-id:flow/*"
                ]
            }
        ]
    }
  3. Attach the Policy to IAM Users, Groups, or Roles: Attach the custom IAM policy to the applicable IAM users, groups, or roles. This ensures that only correctly authenticated and authorized identities can access or modify AppFlow resources.
  4. Regularly Review and Update Permissions: Conduct periodic reviews of the IAM policies and access logs. Update the policy as necessary to revoke any permissions that are no longer needed or to grant any new necessary permissions.

Adhering to these guidelines will help ensure that access to AWS AppFlow resources is properly controlled, minimizing the risk of unauthorized access or actions. For more information on securing your AWS AppFlow resources, refer to the official AWS documentation on AppFlow security best practices.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insufficient data encryption
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data can be intercepted when transferred between various AWS services and third-party SaaS applications if encryption mechanisms are not correctly implemented.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors could exploit unsecured data transfer channels, employing techniques such as network sniffing to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information.
Impacts
The breach could lead to data leakage, unauthorized access to sensitive information, financial losses, reputational damage, and non-compliance with data protection regulations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker monitors network traffic between an AWS service and a connected SaaS application, intercepts unencrypted data transfers, and retrieves confidential customer information, resulting in a severe data breach.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized users gaining access to data flowing through AWS AppFlow can lead to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or compromised credentials. Attack vectors can involve exploiting configuration weaknesses, using phishing schemes to steal credentials, or leveraging malware to gain unauthorized access.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized data access can be severe, including data breaches, loss of sensitive information, legal and compliance issues, reputational damage, and financial losses.
Example Attack Scenarios
A compromised administrative account with weak password protection could be used by an attacker to intercept and exfiltrate data as it flows through AWS AppFlow. Alternatively, a phishing attack that successfully harvests AWS access credentials can be used to gain unauthorized entry to data transfer sessions, leading to a data breach.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of adequate logging and monitoring can delay the detection of unauthorized actions within AWS AppFlow.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include malicious insiders or external attackers exploiting weaknesses in logging and monitoring configurations. They may access or manipulate data without detection due to insufficient monitoring mechanisms.
Impacts
The key impacts include delayed incident response, prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential data breaches, and loss of compliance with regulatory standards.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to AWS AppFlow and starts exfiltrating data. Without adequate logging, their actions go undetected for an extended period, amplifying potential damage. Alternatively, an insider could alter data flow settings without triggering alerts, compromising data integrity and confidentiality.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Data leakage via incorrect flow configuration
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured data flows can result in data being sent to unintended destinations, which may cause sensitive information to be exposed.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers exploiting configuration errors, and accidental misconfigurations by legitimate users. Attack vectors involve manipulating or exploiting AWS AppFlow settings to reroute data flows.
Impacts
The main impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of customer trust, financial penalties, and potential legal action.
Example Attack Scenarios
In one scenario, a misconfigured data flow could inadvertently send customer data to an unauthorized third-party service. In another, an attacker could exploit a configuration error to divert data to a server under their control, gaining access to sensitive information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Anonymize sensitive data in datasets
countermeasure.desc:
Anonymizing data is a crucial step in protecting sensitive information and minimizing the risk of exposing personal data within datasets analyzed by Amazon Athena. By implementing data anonymization, you ensure that personal data is obscured or de-identified, reducing the potential for unauthorized access and data breaches.

To effectively anonymize data in Amazon Athena, follow these guidelines:

  1. Understand Data Sensitivity and Compliance Requirements: Identify the types of sensitive data within your datasets and understand the compliance requirements that apply to your organization. This will help you determine the appropriate level of anonymization needed.
  2. Leverage AWS Lake Formation for Data Governance: Utilize AWS Lake Formation to manage and enforce fine-grained access controls on your datasets. Lake Formation allows you to create and enforce policies that help protect sensitive data. More details can be found in the Anonymize and manage data in your data lake with Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation blog post.
  3. Use Built-in Anonymization Functions: Amazon Athena provides built-in functions to help with data anonymization, such as masking, tokenization, and encryption. For instance, you can use SQL expressions to replace certain data fields with anonymized values. Refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation to learn more about the available functions and how to use them securely.
  4. Implement Field-Level Encryption: Use field-level encryption to encrypt sensitive fields within your datasets. This ensures that even if unauthorized access occurs, the sensitive data remains protected. AWS KMS (Key Management Service) can be used to manage cryptographic keys securely.
  5. Regularly Audit and Monitor Data Access: Conduct regular audits and monitor access to your data. AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config can help you track and log access to your Amazon Athena queries and underlying data stores, providing visibility into user actions and potential security issues.

By following these steps and leveraging the capabilities of Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation, you can effectively anonymize your data, thereby enhancing the security and privacy of the information analyzed within your data lake.

For further reference, consult the official Amazon Athena Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of Athena table data
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data stored in Amazon S3 buckets used by AWS Athena is protected from unauthorized access, configuring encryption at rest is paramount. This involves enabling server-side encryption (SSE) for the relevant S3 buckets. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Navigate to the S3 Management Console in your AWS account.
  2. Select the bucket where Athena stores its data.
  3. Go to the "Properties" tab of the selected bucket.
  4. Locate the "Default encryption" section and click on "Edit."
  5. Choose your preferred encryption method:
    • SSE-S3: Server-Side Encryption with Amazon S3-Managed Keys.
    • SSE-KMS: Server-Side Encryption with AWS Key Management Service (KMS) Keys.
    • SSE-C: Server-Side Encryption with Customer-Provided Keys.
  6. Click "Save changes" to enable or update the encryption settings.

Enabling server-side encryption helps you comply with security standards and protects your sensitive data from unauthorized access. For more detailed instructions, refer to the official AWS documentation on encrypting data in Athena and the overarching security guidelines for Amazon S3 buckets available here.

countermeasure.name: Implement AWS Lake Formation to enforce strict access controls
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing and enforcing detailed access control policies using AWS Lake Formation can significantly enhance the security posture of your data lake environment. AWS Lake Formation provides fine-grained access controls over data stored in Amazon S3, enabling you to restrict access to datasets by granting permissions at the database, table, column, or row level. This ensures only authorized users can access specific datasets, thereby minimizing the risk of unauthorized data access.

To begin, ensure that AWS Lake Formation is set up and integrated with your existing AWS Athena environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Configure AWS Lake Formation: First, navigate to the AWS Lake Formation console. Here, register your Amazon S3 data lake storage resources by specifying the Amazon S3 locations where your data resides. Refer to the AWS Lake Formation Getting Started Guide for detailed instructions.
  2. Define Access Control Policies: Use Lake Formation permissions to grant database, table, and column-level access to specific IAM users or roles. For instance, a policy might restrict access to a table containing sensitive information such as PII (Personally Identifiable Information) to only specific roles. Detailed instructions on defining these policies can be found in the AWS Lake Formation Data Access Control documentation.
  3. Integrate with AWS Athena: Ensure that your AWS Athena queries are compliant with the access controls set in Lake Formation. When users run queries in Athena, Lake Formation credentials automatically enforce the defined permissions, thus controlling access to the datasets. Review the AWS Athena and Lake Formation Integration Guide for implementation details.
  4. Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly monitor and audit access to your datasets using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Lake Formation's audit capabilities. This helps in tracking user activities and ensuring compliance with your organization's security policies. For more details, refer to the Athena CloudTrail Logs documentation and the Lake Formation Auditing documentation.

By leveraging AWS Lake Formation to implement and enforce detailed access control policies, you effectively reduce the risk of unauthorized data access in your Amazon Athena queries, thereby strengthening your overall data security strategy.

countermeasure.name: Secure query result sets
countermeasure.desc:
Storing Query Results in Encrypted S3 Buckets and Restricting Access Using IAM and S3 Bucket Policies

A key measure to secure your AWS Athena query results involves storing them in encrypted Amazon S3 buckets and ensuring that access to these buckets is strictly controlled using IAM and S3 bucket policies. Follow the steps below to implement this control effectively:

Step 1: Create an Encrypted S3 Bucket

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Navigate to the Amazon S3 service.
  3. Create a new S3 bucket, or select an existing one where you want to store the query results.
  4. Ensure that server-side encryption (SSE) is enabled for the bucket. You can use either SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS.

Step 2: Set Up IAM Policies

IAM policies are essential to control which users and roles have permissions to access the S3 bucket and perform actions on it. Follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to the IAM service in the AWS Management Console.
  2. Define a policy that grants necessary permissions to access the specified S3 bucket. You can utilize managed polices or create a custom policy. An example policy could be:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "s3:*",
            "Resource": ["arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name", "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*"]
        }
    ]
}

Attach this policy to the respective IAM roles that need access.

Step 3: Configure S3 Bucket Policies

S3 bucket policies can be used to enforce security controls on a specific bucket. Steps to configure S3 bucket policies:

  1. Select the S3 bucket created in step 1.
  2. Go to the 'Permissions' tab.
  3. Add a bucket policy that restricts access based on IAM roles, specific IP ranges, or conditions, ensuring fine-grained control over who accesses your bucket. A sample policy might look like this:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": {"AWS": "arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/RoleName"},
            "Action": "s3:GetObject",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*",
            "Condition": {
                "IpAddress": {"aws:SourceIp": "your-ip-range"}
            }
        }
    ]
}

By following these procedures, you ensure that your Athena query results are stored securely and that access to these results is tightly controlled. For more detailed information, please refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Use CalledVia context keys
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Athena service, it is crucial to limit requests to AWS Athena by configuring policies to include the aws:CalledVia global condition context key. This ensures requests are made only from authorized services.

Begin by identifying the services that are authorized to make requests to AWS Athena. These could be AWS Lambda functions, AWS Glue, or other AWS services in your environment.

Next, modify the IAM policies associated with your Athena-related roles to include the aws:CalledVia condition. This condition context key allows you to specify the services that are permitted to invoke Athena actions.

Heres a step-by-step guide to implement this:

  1. Identify the IAM roles and policies that need to be updated.
  2. Open the IAM Management Console.
  3. Navigate to the relevant policy you wish to update.
  4. Edit the policy to include the Condition block with the aws:CalledVia context key. 
    
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": "athena:*",
    "Resource": "*",
    "Condition": {
      "StringEquals": {
        "aws:CalledVia": [
          "lambda.amazonaws.com",
          "glue.amazonaws.com"
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}
  5. Apply and save the updated policy.

By including the aws:CalledVia condition context key, you significantly reduce the surface area for unauthorized access to Athena. This control ensures that only requests from specified AWS services, such as Lambda or Glue, are allowed to interact with Athena.

For further details and guidance, please refer to the official AWS Athena security documentation.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Improper result set access
threat.desc:
General threat description
If result sets of Athena queries are not properly secured, they could be accessed by unauthorized users.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel gaining access to improperly secured Athena query result sets through misconfigured access permissions.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, potential compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages misconfigured AWS permissions to access confidential data stored in Athena query results, exposing sensitive information to unauthorized entities.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Unencrypted table data
threat.desc:
General threat description
If data within Athena tables is not encrypted, it may be accessed by unauthorized parties, leading to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or attackers exploiting misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in the AWS environment.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, potential data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and damage to organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS account and finds unencrypted Athena tables containing sensitive data, which they can exfiltrate. A malicious insider with access to Athena tables abuses their permissions to access and share sensitive information without detection.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper anonymization, sensitive data within datasets can be exposed to unauthorized individuals, leading to potential data breaches and privacy violations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and careless or untrained employees. Attack vectors range from direct access to the AWS Athena service without proper anonymization protocols to intercepting data in transit.
Impacts
Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive information, potential legal and compliance violations, loss of customer trust, and significant financial penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An employee queries a dataset in AWS Athena that contains unmasked Personally Identifiable Information (PII). The data is inadvertently shared or accessed by an unauthorized party, leading to a data breach.
Scenario 2: An external attacker leverages a misconfigured access control policy to retrieve sensitive data from AWS Athena, which was not properly anonymized, and uses the data for malicious purposes.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without strict access controls, unauthorized users might gain access to sensitive data, leading to potential data theft or misuse.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external hackers exploiting loose access permissions, and users accidentally sharing access credentials.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive data, financial repercussions, damage to reputation, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious insider with knowledge of the system gains unauthorized access to financial records. An external hacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to access proprietary business information. A user accidentally shares their access credentials with a phishing attacker, compromising customer data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through intermediary services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized or intermediary services interacting with AWS Athena can lead to data leaks or malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, insiders, or unauthorized third-party services exploiting misconfigurations or security gaps.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data, financial loss, compliance violations, and potential damage to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to AWS Athena credentials through a compromised third-party service and executes queries to exfiltrate sensitive information. Alternatively, an insider uses intermediary services to route unauthorized requests, causing data exposure or unauthorized data modification.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

countermeasure.name: Enforce least privilege and regularly audit user permissions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all user profiles in AWS Connect are configured with the minimum permissions necessary to perform their roles effectively. Implement the principle of least privilege by assigning only those permissions required for specific tasks, reducing the risk of unauthorized actions or privilege escalation. Additionally, regularly audit user permissions to identify and remove any excessive or outdated access rights. Use AWS IAM Access Analyzer and other auditing tools to review permission sets and ensure compliance with security policies. This ongoing process helps maintain a secure environment by limiting the potential for internal threats and minimizing the impact of any compromised accounts.

countermeasure.name: Enforce Service Control Policies to protect critical resources from deletion
countermeasure.desc: To maintain the continuity and availability of your AWS Connect services, enforce Service Control Policies (SCPs) that explicitly prevent the deletion of critical resources such as Amazon Connect instances and associated IAM roles. SCPs act as guardrails that limit the actions users and roles can perform, even if they have administrative permissions. Implement an SCP at the organizational level to deny deletion actions (iam:DeleteRole and connect:DeleteInstance) on these critical resources. This ensures that no user or process can accidentally or maliciously remove essential components, safeguarding the stability and security of your contact center environment. Regularly review and update the SCPs to align with any changes in your resource configurations.

countermeasure.name: Implement Content Security Policy (CSP) and secure DOM manipulation in chat applications
countermeasure.desc: To protect against cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks in AWS Connect chat applications, implement a robust Content Security Policy (CSP) that restricts the sources from which your application can load scripts, styles, and other resources. This helps to prevent the execution of malicious code. Additionally, avoid directly mutating the Document Object Model (DOM) by using functions like innerHTML to insert content into the web page. Instead, use secure methods, such as libraries that sanitize and encode user inputs (e.g., React), to render chat responses safely. This practice ensures that any content dynamically added to your web pages does not expose your application to XSS vulnerabilities.

countermeasure.name: Monitor and audit access to recordings and sensitive data
countermeasure.desc: Implement continuous monitoring and auditing of all access to recordings and other sensitive data within AWS Connect to detect and prevent unauthorized access. Use AWS CloudTrail to log all requests and actions related to sensitive resources, and set up alerts for any suspicious or unusual activity. Ensure that access logs are stored securely and reviewed regularly for compliance and security purposes. Additionally, restrict access to sensitive data to only those users and roles that absolutely need it, and use fine-grained permissions to minimize exposure. This approach helps in early detection of potential breaches and ensures that all access to critical data is accountable and traceable.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion of critical resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Accidental deletion of critical resources refers to the unintentional removal of essential components within AWS Connect, such as instances, IAM roles, or configuration settings. This can occur due to user error or misconfigured automation scripts, leading to significant disruptions in service availability and functionality.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Internal users with elevated permissions, automated processes, or misconfigured scripts.
  • Attack Vectors: Unintended actions by administrators, such as mistakenly deleting key resources, or poorly tested scripts that remove critical components.

Impacts

  • Service Disruption: Loss of availability for AWS Connect services, potentially leading to downtime for customer-facing applications.
  • Data Loss: Permanent deletion of important data or configurations that are crucial for service operations.
  • Recovery Challenges: Time-consuming and complex recovery processes that might involve restoring from backups or reconfiguring services from scratch.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An administrator mistakenly deletes the primary Amazon Connect instance instead of a test environment, causing an immediate service outage and requiring a full recovery operation.
  2. A poorly tested automation script unintentionally removes IAM roles associated with AWS Connect, cutting off user access and disrupting operations until roles are recreated and permissions are restored.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate user permission management
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate User Permission Management occurs when users are granted excessive permissions within AWS Connect, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data and critical operations. This mismanagement increases the risk of data breaches and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Internal employees, contractors, or external attackers with access to overly permissive accounts.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting misconfigured IAM roles or compromised credentials to perform unauthorized actions.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive customer information.
  • Service Disruption: Unintended or malicious changes causing service outages.
  • Compliance Risks: Violations of legal standards like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A user with excessive permissions deletes a critical Amazon Connect instance, causing service downtime.
  2. An attacker with admin access siphons off sensitive call recordings, leading to a data breach.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized access to sensitive data occurs when individuals, either internal or external, gain access to confidential information within AWS Connect without proper authorization. This can lead to data breaches, where sensitive customer or organizational information is exposed or exploited.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users exploiting weak access controls.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting poorly managed permissions, compromised credentials, or unmonitored access points.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of personal customer data, leading to financial and reputational damage.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of legal and regulatory requirements, such as GDPR, resulting in fines.
  • Trust Erosion: Loss of customer trust and potential revenue decline due to perceived insecurity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses stolen credentials to access and download customer call recordings, leading to a significant data breach.
  2. An insider with unauthorized access retrieves sensitive client information and sells it on the black market, compromising customer privacy and trust.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Vulnerabilities in chat integration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Vulnerabilities in chat integration arise when security flaws in the implementation of chat features within AWS Connect allow attackers to exploit these weaknesses, potentially leading to unauthorized access, data leakage, or injection of malicious code. This is particularly critical when chat systems are integrated directly into web applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious users, or automated bots targeting weak points in chat functionality.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities, injecting malicious payloads via chat inputs, or intercepting unencrypted chat communications.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive customer interactions and data transmitted via chat could be intercepted or manipulated.
  • Service Disruption: Exploiting vulnerabilities to disrupt the chat service or degrade user experience.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust due to compromised chat functionality and potential data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits an XSS vulnerability in the chat interface, injecting malicious scripts that execute in the browser of anyone interacting with the chat, leading to data theft or account compromise.
  2. A poorly secured chat integration allows an attacker to hijack chat sessions, impersonate customer support, and obtain sensitive information from unsuspecting customers.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Consider client-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you plan your encryption strategy before implementing your table in DynamoDB. If you store sensitive or confidential data in DynamoDB, consider including client-side encryption in your plan. This way you can encrypt data as close as possible to its origin, and ensure its protection throughout its lifecycle. Encrypting your sensitive data in transit and at rest helps ensure that your plaintext data isnt available to any third party.

The AWS Database Encryption SDK for DynamoDB is a software library that helps you protect your table data before you send it to DynamoDB. It encrypts, signs, verifies, and decrypts your DynamoDB table items. You control which attributes are encrypted and signed.

SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Monitor DynamoDB operations using CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
CloudTrail can monitor both control plane events and data plane events. Control plane operations let you create and manage DynamoDB tables. They also let you work with indexes, streams, and other objects that are dependent on tables. Data plane operations let you perform create, read, update, and delete (also called CRUD) actions on data in a table. Some data plane operations also let you read data from a secondary index. To enable logging of data plane events in CloudTrail, you'll need to enable logging of data plane API activity in CloudTrail. See Logging data events for trails for more information.

When activity occurs in DynamoDB, that activity is recorded in a CloudTrail event along with other AWS service events in the event history. For more information, see Logging DynamoDB Operations by Using AWS CloudTrail. You can view, search, and download recent events in your AWS account. For more information, see Viewing Events with CloudTrail Event History in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

For an ongoing record of events in your AWS account, including events for DynamoDB, create a trail. A trail enables CloudTrail to deliver log files to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket. By default, when you create a trail on the console, the trail applies to all AWS Regions. The trail logs events from all Regions in the AWS partition and delivers the log files to the S3 bucket that you specify. Additionally, you can configure other AWS services to further analyze and act upon the event data collected in CloudTrail logs.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Config to monitor configuration changes and ensure compliance with security policies
countermeasure.desc:
Using AWS Config, you can continuously monitor and record configuration changes of your AWS resources. You can also use AWS Config to inventory your AWS resources. When a change from a previous state is detected, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification can be delivered for you to review and take action. Follow the guidance in Setting Up AWS Config with the Console, ensuring that DynamoDB resource types are included.

You can configure AWS Config to stream configuration changes and notifications to an Amazon SNS topic. For example, when a resource is updated, you can get a notification sent to your email, so that you can view the changes. You can also be notified when AWS Config evaluates your custom or managed rules against your resources.

For an example, see Notifications that AWS Config Sends to an Amazon SNS topic in the AWS Config Developer Guide.
