countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB's encryption at rest to secure data stored in tables, backups, and streams
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB encrypts at rest all user data stored in tables, indexes, streams, and backups using encryption keys stored in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). This provides an additional layer of data protection by securing your data from unauthorized access to the underlying storage .

You can specify whether DynamoDB should use an AWS owned key (default encryption type), an AWS managed key, or a customer managed key to encrypt user data. For more information, see Amazon DynamoDB Encryption at Rest.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB Streams to monitor data plane operations
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB is integrated with AWS Lambda so that you can create triggerspieces of code that automatically respond to events in DynamoDB Streams. With triggers, you can build applications that react to data modifications in DynamoDB tables.

If you enable DynamoDB Streams on a table, you can associate the stream Amazon Resource Name (ARN) with a Lambda function that you write. Immediately after an item in the table is modified, a new record appears in the table's stream. AWS Lambda polls the stream and invokes your Lambda function synchronously when it detects new stream records. The Lambda function can perform any actions that you specify, such as sending a notification or initiating a workflow.

For an example, see Tutorial: Using AWS Lambda with Amazon DynamoDB Streams. This example receives a DynamoDB event input, processes the messages that it contains, and writes some of the incoming event data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM policy conditions for fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
When you grant permissions in DynamoDB, you can specify conditions that determine how a permissions policy takes effect. Implementing least privilege is key in reducing security risk and the impact that can result from errors or malicious intent.

You can specify conditions when granting permissions using an IAM policy. For example, you can do the following:

  • Grant permissions to allow users read-only access to certain items and attributes in a table or a secondary index.
  • Grant permissions to allow users write-only access to certain attributes in a table, based upon the identity of that user.

For more information, see Using IAM Policy Conditions for Fine-Grained Access Control.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improperly configured IAM policies can lead to unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improperly configured IAM (Identity and Access Management) policies in AWS can result in unauthorized access to DynamoDB tables. These policies govern who can access what resources and with what permissions. Misconfigurations can accidentally grant excessive privileges, allowing unauthorized users to read, write, or delete data, thereby compromising the security of the DynamoDB service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include internal users such as employees or administrators who might misconfigure policies either accidentally or intentionally. External attackers can exploit stolen AWS credentials or use social engineering techniques to gain access. Automation tools with misconfigured permissions can also inadvertently expose sensitive data.

Impacts

The impacts of this threat include data breaches where sensitive information is exposed, data integrity issues from unauthorized modifications, service disruptions due to unauthorized configuration changes, and potential non-compliance with regulatory requirements, leading to legal and financial repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator accidentally grants excessive permissions to a DynamoDB table, allowing unauthorized internal applications to modify data. A phishing attack leads to compromised AWS credentials, which are then used to exploit an overly permissive policy, resulting in a data breach. A malicious insider with policy management privileges misconfigures policies to gain access to sensitive data, leaking it to external parties. An automation script with broad IAM permissions inadvertently changes access controls, exposing data to unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data transmitted over the network can be intercepted by malicious actors
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data transmitted over a network can be intercepted by malicious actors using various techniques such as man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, or session hijacking. In the context of AWS DynamoDB, data in transit between clients and the database service may be vulnerable if not adequately protected. Intercepted data can lead to exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized access, and manipulation of data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include cybercriminals, hackers, or state-sponsored actors who intercept data using MitM attacks, deploying tools to capture network traffic, or exploiting vulnerabilities in network security protocols. These attackers may gain access through compromised network infrastructure, unsecured Wi-Fi networks, or by exploiting weak encryption standards.

Impacts

The interception of data in transit can result in data breaches, exposing sensitive information such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property. It can also lead to unauthorized data manipulation, where the integrity and authenticity of the data are compromised. Additionally, it may cause loss of trust, reputational damage, and potential legal consequences for failing to protect customer data.

Example Attack Scenarios

A hacker sets up a MitM attack on an unsecured Wi-Fi network, intercepting data transmitted between a client application and the DynamoDB service, capturing sensitive information like authentication tokens and customer data. An attacker uses packet sniffing tools on a compromised network to monitor and extract data being transferred in plaintext due to lack of encryption. A cybercriminal exploits a vulnerability in a network protocol to hijack an active session between a user and the DynamoDB service, gaining unauthorized access to modify and steal data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: Without proper monitoring, security incidents can go undetected, leading to prolonged exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Without proper monitoring, security incidents involving AWS DynamoDB can go undetected, allowing malicious activities to persist and causing prolonged exposure to threats. Continuous monitoring is essential for detecting unauthorized access, suspicious activities, and potential security breaches in real-time. Lack of monitoring can result in delayed response to security incidents, increasing the risk of data compromise and operational disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated threats such as malware. Attack vectors can involve exploiting vulnerabilities, using stolen credentials, and performing unauthorized data access or modifications. Absence of monitoring tools and alerting mechanisms makes it easier for these threats to operate undetected over extended periods.

Impacts

Undetected security incidents can lead to severe impacts, including prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive data, extensive data breaches, significant financial losses, and reputational damage. Additionally, prolonged exposure increases the complexity and cost of incident response and recovery, while also potentially resulting in regulatory non-compliance and legal penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

An external attacker exploits a vulnerability to gain access to DynamoDB and exfiltrates sensitive data over several months without detection due to lack of monitoring. A malicious insider continuously accesses and manipulates confidential information in DynamoDB, undetected due to insufficient logging and alerting. Malware infects an application accessing DynamoDB, gradually exfiltrating data without triggering any alerts because of inadequate monitoring. Anomalous access patterns indicating a security breach go unnoticed due to the absence of real-time monitoring and analysis tools.

threat.name: Sensitive data stored in DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in AWS DynamoDB can be exposed if not properly secured, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access. This can occur due to misconfigurations, inadequate access controls, lack of encryption, or insufficient monitoring. Ensuring that sensitive information such as personal, financial, or proprietary data is protected is critical to maintaining data confidentiality and integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders with sufficient access privileges, external attackers exploiting misconfigured permissions or vulnerabilities, and automated scripts or applications with excessive access rights. Attack vectors can include exploiting weak or default configurations, leveraging compromised credentials, or taking advantage of unencrypted data storage.

Impacts

The exposure of sensitive data can lead to significant consequences such as identity theft, financial loss, damage to reputation, and legal penalties for non-compliance with data protection regulations. Organizations may face operational disruptions, loss of customer trust, and competitive disadvantages if proprietary information is leaked.

Example Attack Scenarios

An insider with administrative privileges accesses and exfiltrates sensitive customer data stored in DynamoDB for personal gain. An external attacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to gain unauthorized access to financial records stored in DynamoDB. A developer accidentally deploys an application with excessive permissions, allowing it to read and expose sensitive data. Lack of encryption at rest results in an attacker accessing unprotected sensitive information directly from the storage medium.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Choose Amazon EKS Managed Node Groups, which are maintained by Amazon for enhanced security
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon EKS managed node groups provide automated infrastructure management, ensuring nodes are always running the latest Amazon EKS-optimized AMIs with the latest security patches. By using Amazon EKS managed node groups, you can reduce the operational burden on your team and enhance the security posture of your Kubernetes clusters.

To implement this control:

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Open the Amazon EKS console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/eks.
  3. Select the cluster where you want to create a managed node group.
  4. In the left navigation pane, choose Compute, then select Add node group.
  5. Follow the wizard to specify details for your managed node group, such as node group name, AMI type, instance type, and scaling configuration.
  6. Ensure the latest Amazon EKS-optimized AMI is selected to benefit from the latest security patches automatically managed by Amazon.
  7. Review the settings and create the managed node group.

Refer to the AWS official documentation for managed node groups for detailed instructions: Managed Node Groups.

For more insights into securing your EKS cluster, refer to the Amazon EKS Security Best Practices document.

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Implement Amazon EKS managed policies for restricted access
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain a secure Amazon EKS (Elastic Kubernetes Service) environment, it is crucial to implement managed policies that restrict access to the master cluster resources based on the principle of least privilege. Amazon EKS provides managed policies facilitating this security requirement.

Follow the steps below to apply these managed policies:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Begin by identifying the specific permissions required for each user or role interacting with the EKS cluster. Managed policies like AmazonEKSClusterPolicy and AmazonEKSServicePolicy provide a predefined set of permissions tailored for EKS operations. Refer to the AWS EKS Security Docs for more details.
  2. Create IAM Roles or Users: Create IAM roles or users that will interact with your EKS cluster. Ensure that you assign only the necessary permissions to each role or user to adhere to the least privilege principle.
  3. Attach Managed Policies: Attach the relevant managed policies to the IAM roles or users created. Use the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs to perform the attachment. Heres an example CLI command to attach a managed policy to an existing role:aws iam attach-role-policy --role-name YOUR_ROLE_NAME --policy-arn arn:aws:iam::aws:policy/AmazonEKSClusterPolicy
  4. Validate and Test: Once the managed policies are applied, validate and test to ensure appropriate access restrictions are in place. Monitor access logs and IAM policies to confirm that the least privilege access is enforced.

By following these guidelines and utilizing Amazon EKS managed policies, you can effectively secure your master cluster resources while maintaining necessary operational functionalities.

References: AWS EKS Security Documentation

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Implement AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles and policies to limit access to the Kubernetes API server
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing IAM roles and policies is a critical measure to ensure that only authorized users and services have access to the Kubernetes API server in your Amazon EKS Cluster. This countermeasure helps enforce the principle of least privilege, reducing the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches. Below is a step-by-step guide to implement this security control based on the official AWS security guidelines:

  1. Create IAM Policies:
    Create specific IAM policies that define the permissions required to access and interact with the Kubernetes API server. Ensure these policies adhere strictly to the least privilege principle.

    {        "Version": "2012-10-17",        "Statement": [            {                "Effect": "Allow",                "Action": "eks:*",                "Resource": "*"            }        ]    }
     
  2. Associate IAM Policies with IAM Roles:
    Create IAM roles that will be used by users and applications requiring access to the API server. Attach the previously created IAM policies to these roles.
  3. Map IAM Roles to Kubernetes RBAC:
    Use the AWS-auth ConfigMap to map IAM roles to Kubernetes RBAC (Role-Based Access Control).apiVersion: v1 kind: ConfigMap metadata:  name: aws-auth  namespace: kube-system data:  mapRoles: |    - rolearn: arn:aws:iam:::role/      username:      groups:        - system:masters
    For more detailed information, refer to the Add User or Role to EKS Cluster documentation.
  4. Periodically Review IAM Policies and Roles:
    Regularly audit and review IAM policies and roles to ensure that they still adhere to the least privilege principle and update them as necessary to accommodate any changes in your security requirements. For additional details, refer to the IAM Policies User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Implement Pod Security Standards (PSS) to manage security-sensitive elements of the pod specification
countermeasure.desc:
Pod Security Standards (PSS) provide a framework for managing security-sensitive aspects of pod specifications, ensuring consistent, scalable, and secure configurations for workloads in your Amazon EKS clusters. By implementing PSS, cloud engineers can enforce Kubernetes-native security profiles (Privileged, Baseline, Restricted) to protect workloads from misconfigurations and potential vulnerabilities.

Amazon EKS fully supports the adoption of PSS as the recommended alternative to legacy Pod Security Policies (PSPs), aligning with Kubernetes security best practices and enabling streamlined pod security management.

Actionable Steps to Implement PSS

Understand the PSS Profiles:

  • Privileged: Suitable for workloads requiring minimal restrictions.
  • Baseline: A standard for most workloads, ensuring no overly permissive configurations.
  • Restricted: The most secure profile, adhering to the principle of least privilege.

Enable Pod Security Admission Controllers:

  • Utilize the Kubernetes Admission Controller to enforce PSS profiles at runtime.
  • Configure the appropriate profile for each namespace, aligning with workload security requirements.

Integrate PSS Enforcement with CI/CD Pipelines:

  • Update your CI/CD pipelines to validate Kubernetes manifests against PSS profiles during the build process.
  • Use tools like kubectl or third-party validators to ensure compliance with PSS policies before deployment.

Monitor Policy Violations:

  • Enable Kubernetes audit logging to monitor and report policy violations.
  • Integrate AWS CloudWatch or other logging solutions for real-time visibility into policy enforcement and violations.

Iterate and Evolve Policies:

  • Regularly review and update the assigned PSS profiles to align with evolving security needs and compliance standards.
  • Conduct periodic security audits to ensure workloads remain compliant with PSS policies.

Benefits of Implementing PSS

  • Standardization: PSS ensures consistent application of security policies across all workloads.
  • Scalability: Profiles can be applied and enforced at the namespace level, reducing administrative overhead.
  • Compliance: Aligns with Kubernetes direction, ensuring compatibility and reducing operational risk.

For additional guidance, refer to:

  • AWS EKS Documentation: Pod Security Standards
  • AWS Blog: Implementing Pod Security Standards in Amazon EKS
  • AWS FAQ: Pod Security Policy Removal

countermeasure.name: Migrate from Legacy Pod Security Policies (PSP)
countermeasure.desc:
Transitioning from legacy Pod Security Policies (PSPs) to modern alternatives is a critical step to strengthen the security posture of your AWS EKS clusters. PSPs, now deprecated and set for removal, are no longer a viable long-term solution for restricting pod behavior. Instead, AWS recommends adopting Kubernetes' Pod Security Standards (PSS), which provide a more robust and standardized framework for securing workloads.

Actionable Steps:

Audit Current PSP Usage:

  • Identify any existing PSP configurations in your cluster by reviewing your Kubernetes manifests and role-based access control (RBAC) bindings.
  • Use tools like kubectl to list active PSPs and associated workloads.

Plan Migration to PSS:

  • Familiarize yourself with the three profiles offered by PSS: Privileged, Baseline, and Restricted. These profiles correspond to varying levels of security restrictions.
  • Map your current PSP configurations to the equivalent PSS profiles by analyzing workload requirements and security objectives.

Implement Pod Security Admission Controllers:

  • Enable the Kubernetes Admission Controller for Pod Security in your EKS clusters to enforce PSS profiles during workload deployments.
  • Update CI/CD pipelines to validate manifests against PSS standards pre-deployment.

Test and Validate:

  • Deploy workloads with the new PSS profiles applied to ensure compatibility and minimal disruption.
  • Monitor for policy violations using Kubernetes audit logs or integrate with AWS CloudWatch for visibility.

Document and Maintain Compliance:

  • Maintain documentation on adopted profiles and their mapping to workloads.
  • Regularly review and update PSS policies to align with changing security and compliance requirements.

Why Migrate?

AWS EKS has officially deprecated PSPs, and they are slated for removal from Kubernetes versions 1.25 onwards. Continuing to rely on PSPs exposes your clusters to future compatibility issues and potential vulnerabilities. The migration to PSS ensures that your cluster remains secure, compliant, and up to date with Kubernetes best practices.

For detailed guidance on PSP removal and alternatives, consult the AWS FAQ on Pod Security Policy Removal.

Additional Resources:

  • AWS Documentation: Pod Security Policy
  • AWS Blog: Implementing Pod Security Standards in Amazon EKS

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)

countermeasure.name: Regularly update and patch your node
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly updating and patching your EKS nodes is crucial to protect against vulnerabilities and security threats. To effectively implement this, follow these steps:

  1. Regularly monitor AWS security bulletins and the AWS Security Bulletins page to stay informed about the latest patches and updates.
  2. Use the Amazon EKS optimized AMIs (Amazon Machine Images) which are specifically designed and regularly updated by AWS to include the latest security patches.
  3. Configure a maintenance window for your clusters, where you can safely update and patch node groups without affecting the applications availability.
  4. Automate patch management by utilizing services such as AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager to manage and deploy patches across your EKS nodes.
  5. Consider using managed node groups which facilitate easy updates and maintenance by AWS, reducing the operational burden on your team.
  6. Regularly rotate and replace old nodes to ensure they are running the latest patched versions of AMIs.
  7. Integrate continuous monitoring tools to regularly check the status and version of your nodes, ensuring they remain compliant with security best practices.

For detailed guidelines, refer to the AWS EKS Security Best Practices documentation.

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1028 - Operating System Configuration

countermeasure.name: Set up Kubernetes network policies to manage traffic flow between pods
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Kubernetes network policies within AWS EKS enhances the security posture of your cluster by regulating the traffic flow between pods, ensuring that only authorized communication paths are permitted. Below are the steps a cloud engineer should follow to configure these policies:

Enable Network Policies: AWS EKS supports network policies via the Calico plugin. It is essential to ensure that the EKS cluster is set up with network policy support. Refer to the EKS official documentation on Calico Network Policies to enable this feature.

Define Network Policies: Create NetworkPolicy resources to specify how groups of pods are allowed to communicate with each other and other network endpoints. The policies can specify allowed ingress and egress traffic. Here is an example of a network policy YAML file:

  1.        apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1    kind: NetworkPolicy    metadata:      name: allow-specific-service      namespace: your-namespace    spec:      podSelector:        matchLabels:          role: your-app      policyTypes:      - Ingress      - Egress      ingress:      - from:        - ipBlock:            cidr: 192.168.0.0/16      egress:      - to:        - ipBlock:            cidr: 100.64.0.0/10        

Apply the Network Policies: Use kubectl to apply the NetworkPolicy resource to your cluster:

  1. kubectl apply -f your-network-policy.yaml

Test the Configuration: Once the network policies are applied, it is crucial to test them to validate that the traffic flow is as expected. You can use network testing tools or custom scripts for validation.

Following these steps helps ensure that your EKS cluster leverages network policies effectively, enhancing its security. For more detailed information, refer to the AWS EKS Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Secrets Manager to store and manage secrets
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard sensitive information within AWS EKS, it is crucial to store and manage secrets effectively using AWS Secrets Manager. This service enables you to securely store and manage access to secrets such as database credentials, API keys, and other confidential data.

Implementation Guidance

  1. Create a Secret in AWS Secrets Manager: Use the AWS Secrets Manager console, AWS CLI, or SDK to create a new secret. Follow the steps provided in the AWS Secrets Manager User Guide to set up your secrets correctly.
  2. IAM Policy Configuration: Configure Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to control access to the secrets. Ensure that only authorized roles and users have permission to read or manage secrets. Detailed policies can be implemented as outlined in the AWS EKS Security Documentation.
  3. Integrate with Kubernetes: Use Kubernetes Secrets to integrate with AWS Secrets Manager. Create an ExternalSecrets resource that references the secrets stored in AWS Secrets Manager. This can be done using tools like the AWS Secrets and Configuration Provider (ASCP) for Kubernetes.
  4. Monitor and Rotate Secrets: Regularly monitor the usage of secrets and implement automatic rotation policies for enhanced security. AWS Secrets Manager supports automatic rotation of secrets, which can be configured as detailed in the Secrets Manager Rotation Guide.

By following these steps, you can leverage AWS Secrets Manager to securely manage sensitive information in your AWS EKS environments. For more detailed guidance, refer to the official AWS EKS Security Documentation.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated Pod Security Policies
threat.desc:
General threat description
Use of deprecated or improperly configured Pod Security Policies (PSP) can result in leaving workloads vulnerable, facilitating unauthorized access and privilege escalation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders or external attackers who exploit misconfigured or deprecated PSPs to gain unauthorized access or elevate privileges within a Kubernetes environment.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized control over Kubernetes workloads, and potential disruption of services.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a deprecated PSP setup and uses it to bypass security controls, gaining administrative access to containers and escalating their privileges across the cluster, potentially accessing confidential information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1063 - Security Software Discovery

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Cluster access control issues
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control can allow unauthorized users to interact with the Kubernetes cluster, leading to potential compromise and data leaks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders or external attackers exploiting weak authentication mechanisms, misconfigured IAM (Identity and Access Management) roles, or overly permissive access policies. Attack vectors could involve gaining access to Kubernetes API servers, exploiting unsecured endpoints, or leveraging compromised credentials to interact with the cluster.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to a Kubernetes cluster can be severe, including unauthorized data access, service disruptions, deployment of malicious containers, and potential breaching of customer data. The compromised environment could also be used to launch attacks on other systems within the same network.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker finds an exposed Kubernetes API server with weak authentication and gains full administrative access to the cluster. 2. A malicious insider abuses overly permissive IAM roles to deploy a malicious container image that exfiltrates sensitive data from the cluster. 3. Compromised credentials obtained through phishing are used to bypass access controls, allowing the attacker to tamper with configurations and disrupt services running on the cluster.

threat.name: Exposure of secrets and environment variables
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing sensitive information like credentials and tokens in pods without proper encryption can lead to unauthorized access, compromising the security of your Kubernetes environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized individuals who gain access to the pod can easily extract sensitive information if it is stored in plain text. This could happen through compromised accounts, malware, or insider threats.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to critical resources, data breaches, potential financial losses, and harm to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a pod and finds unencrypted credentials stored in environment variables or configuration files. They use these credentials to access databases, APIs, or other services, leading to data exfiltration and operational disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores

threat.name: Inadequate network policies
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of defined network policies can allow unrestricted communication between pods, leading to potential security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors who gain access to a compromised pod can potentially move laterally within the Kubernetes cluster without restriction.
Impacts
This can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data, compromise of multiple services, and the spread of malicious activity throughout the cluster.
Example Attack Scenarios
A compromised pod could be used as a foothold to access and exfiltrate data from other pods, escalate privileges, or disrupt services by leveraging the lack of restrictive network policies.

threat.name: Compromised nodes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Compromised nodes can have a broad impact on the entire Kubernetes environment by potentially facilitating unauthorized access, data leakage, and increasing cluster management risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Adversaries can exploit vulnerabilities in the Kubernetes nodes, deploy malicious containers, or misuse node-level permissions to gain control over the nodes. This may be initiated through insecure APIs, exploited software vulnerabilities, or weak authentication mechanisms.
Impacts
The impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of service, loss of data integrity, and potential takeover of the entire cluster, which could lead to downtime and significant security breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits a zero-day vulnerability in the container runtime on a Kubernetes node, gaining root access, and subsequently exfiltrates sensitive data stored in the node. 2. Using stolen node credentials, an attacker deploys a malicious container that scans and exploits other nodes in the cluster, increasing their control and compromising additional resources. 3. A security misconfiguration allows an adversary to execute arbitrary commands on a node, leading to data manipulation and unauthorized access to inter-node communication.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Lack of standardized Pod Security
threat.desc:
General threat description
The absence of standardized security practices can lead to vulnerabilities in AWS EKS configurations, potentially resulting in unauthorized access or manipulation of pod integrity and violations of security compliance. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigurations or weak security settings in the EKS environment to gain unauthorized access to Kubernetes pods or interfere with their operations. 
Impacts
Compromised pod integrity can lead to data breaches, service disruptions, and failure to meet compliance requirements, which can harm organizational reputation and result in financial losses. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers that role-based access controls (RBAC) are improperly configured, allowing unauthorized users to escalate privileges and modify running pods. Another scenario could involve an attacker exploiting the lack of network policies to perform a lateral movement attack between pods, accessing sensitive information across the cluster.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Assign specific IAM roles to AWS Glue jobs at the time of creation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and manage permissions efficiently within your AWS Glue environment, assign specific IAM roles to AWS Glue jobs at the time of creation. This practice ensures that each job runs with only the necessary permissions required for its operation, adhering to the principle of least privilege. This minimizes the risk of unauthorized actions and potential security breaches.

Implementation Guidance:

Create an IAM Role for AWS Glue Jobs:

  • Navigate to the IAM console in the AWS Management Console.
  • Choose "Roles" and then "Create role".
  • Select "Glue" as the service that will use the role.
  • Attach the necessary policies that define the permissions for the Glue job. Ensure the policies grant only the permissions required for the job's specific tasks.

Define Permissions Policies:

  • Use managed policies provided by AWS or create custom policies to fine-tune the permissions.

Assign the IAM Role to a Glue Job:

  • When creating a new Glue job in the AWS Glue console, specify the IAM role under the "IAM role" field.
  • For existing jobs, you can update the role by navigating to the job's configuration and editing the "IAM role" field.

Use the AWS CLI or AWS SDKs:

  • You can also assign roles programmatically when creating or updating jobs using the AWS CLI or SDKs.
  • Example using AWS CLI:

aws glue create-job --name MyGlueJob --role arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/GlueJobRole --command 'Name=glueetl,ScriptLocation=s3://my-script-location'

Regularly Review and Rotate IAM Roles:

  • Periodically review the permissions associated with IAM roles to ensure they are still appropriate.
  • Rotate roles and credentials as part of a security best practice to mitigate the risk of compromised credentials.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Glue Documentation on IAM Roles and the IAM Best Practices.

reference.name: CWE-284: CWE-284
Configuring job properties for Spark jobs in AWS Glue
Security best practices in IAM

countermeasure.name: Implement encryption for the AWS Glue Data Catalog to protect metadata at rest
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Glue Data Catalog encryption provides enhanced security for your sensitive data. AWS Glue integrates with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) to encrypt metadata that's stored in the Data Catalog. You can enable or disable encryption settings for resources in the Data Catalog using the AWS Glue console or the AWS CLI.

When you enable encryption for your Data Catalog, all new objects that you create will be encrypted. When you disable encryption, the new objects you create will not be encrypted, but existing encrypted objects will remain encrypted.

You can encrypt your entire Data Catalog using AWS managed encryption keys or customer managed encryption keys. For more information on key types and states, see AWS Key Management Service concepts in the AWS Key Management Service Developer Guide.

reference.name: CWE-326: CWE-326
Encrypting your Data Catalog
Encryption at rest

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Insufficient access control measures for AWS Glue jobs can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of data processing activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient access control measures for AWS Glue jobs can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of data processing activities. When permissions are not properly restricted, malicious actors or uninformed users could exploit these permissions to perform unauthorized actions within Glue jobs. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external actors with some level of access to the AWS environment may exploit weak or misconfigured IAM roles and policies associated with Glue jobs. This exploitation could be executed through compromised user accounts, overly permissive roles, or inadvertent user error. 
Impacts
The primary impacts include unauthorized data access, data corruption, service disruption, and potential data loss. Confidential or sensitive data could be compromised, leading to reputational damage and regulatory compliance penalties. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An internal user with insufficiently restricted permissions modifies a Glue job to exfiltrate sensitive data to an external location. 
2. A compromised account with access to Glue jobs alters data processing logic, resulting in corrupted or incorrect data outputs. 
3. Overly permissive permissions granted to a third-party contractor allow them to access and manipulate Glue jobs, leading to unintended data exposure.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to metadata in AWS Glue can allow malicious actors to obtain sensitive information
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to metadata in AWS Glue can allow malicious actors to obtain sensitive information about your data catalog, ETL jobs, and other resources. This meta-information can be used to orchestrate further attacks or exfiltrate sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers who have gained access through compromised credentials, or internal users with unnecessary permissions. Attack vectors can include exploiting misconfigurations in IAM policies, improper permission settings, or vulnerabilities in the AWS Glue service itself.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to metadata include the potential exposure of sensitive data structures, revealing business-critical information, loss of intellectual property, and the possibility of launching subsequent attacks using the gleaned metadata. It can also lead to a loss of customer trust and regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker obtains credentials from a low-privileged user but finds that IAM policies are misconfigured, allowing access to AWS Glue metadata. The attacker then retrieves details about ETL jobs and uses this information to identify data storage locations to exfiltrate data. 
2. An internal employee with broader-than-necessary permissions accesses metadata about critical ETL jobs and alters the job configurations to reroute sensitive data to an external location under their control. 
3. Exploiting a vulnerability in AWS Glue, an attacker circumvents authentication mechanisms to access metadata directly, gaining insights into the organizations data structures and using this information to identify soft targets for further attacks.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

  • For existing jobs, you can update the role by navigating to the job's configuration and editing the "IAM role" field.

Use the AWS CLI or AWS SDKs:

  • You can also assign roles programmatically when creating or updating jobs using the AWS CLI or SDKs.
  • Example using AWS CLI:

aws glue create-job --name MyGlueJob --role arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/GlueJobRole --command 'Name=glueetl,ScriptLocation=s3://my-script-location'

Regularly Review and Rotate IAM Roles:

  • Periodically review the permissions associated with IAM roles to ensure they are still appropriate.
  • Rotate roles and credentials as part of a security best practice to mitigate the risk of compromised credentials.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Glue Documentation on IAM Roles and the IAM Best Practices.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS CloudTrail for Kinesis Data Streams
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure visibility and traceability of all actions within AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enable AWS CloudTrail to log all API calls. This practice helps detect unauthorized activities and provides a comprehensive audit trail for security reviews. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Enable CloudTrail:

  • Navigate to the AWS CloudTrail console.
  • Create a new trail or use an existing trail.
  • Ensure the trail applies to all regions to capture all API activity.

Configure Logging:

  • Specify an S3 bucket for log storage with proper access controls and encryption.
  • Optionally, enable log file validation for added security.

Set Up Monitoring and Alerts:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch to set up metrics and alarms based on specific API activity patterns.
  • Configure CloudWatch Alarms to alert security personnel when suspicious or unusual API calls are detected.

Review and Analyze Logs:

  • Regularly review CloudTrail logs to identify and investigate unauthorized or suspicious API calls.
  • Use AWS CloudTrail Insights for automated analysis and detection of unusual activity.

reference.name: Logging Amazon Kinesis Data Streams API Calls with AWS CloudTrail

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

countermeasure.name: Enable server-side encryption for Kinesis Data Streams
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data at rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enable server-side encryption (SSE) using AWS KMS-managed keys. This ensures that data is automatically encrypted before being written to the stream and decrypted when read. Follow these steps:

Enable Server-Side Encryption:

  • Navigate to the Kinesis Data Streams console.
  • Select the data stream you want to encrypt.
  • In the stream details, enable server-side encryption.
  • Choose an AWS KMS key to manage the encryption. You can use an AWS-managed key or a customer-managed key (CMK).

Verify Encryption Status:

  • Check the stream details to ensure that SSE is enabled and the correct KMS key is being used.
  • Verify that new data being ingested into the stream is encrypted.

Update IAM Policies:

  • Ensure that IAM roles and policies allow access to the KMS keys used for encryption and decryption.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail to log and monitor all access to KMS keys and Kinesis Data Streams.
  • Set up CloudWatch alarms for unusual access patterns or failures in encryption/decryption operations.

reference.name: Data Protection in Amazon Kinesis Data Streams

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unencrypted Data at Rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams refers to the risk posed by storing data in Kinesis streams without encryption. This can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive information if someone gains access to the storage backend. Encrypting data at rest ensures that even if physical storage media is compromised, the data remains protected and inaccessible to unauthorized users.

Threat Agents:

  • External attackers gaining access to storage media.
  • Malicious insiders with access to storage backend.
  • Unauthorized users exploiting vulnerabilities to access stored data.

Attack Vectors:

  • Physical theft or compromise of storage media.
  • Exploitation of software vulnerabilities that allow access to unencrypted data.
  • Misconfigured access controls allowing unauthorized access to storage resources.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information stored in Kinesis Data Streams, leading to potential data leaks and compliance issues.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Potential alteration of data by unauthorized entities, leading to unreliable or corrupted data.
  • Compliance Violations: Storing unencrypted data may violate industry regulations and standards, leading to legal penalties and reputational damage.
  • Reputation Damage: Security incidents involving unencrypted data can erode customer trust and damage the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Physical Compromise: An external attacker gains physical access to AWS data centers or backup media. Without encryption, the attacker can read sensitive data directly from the storage devices.
  2. Insider Threat: A malicious insider with access to the storage infrastructure retrieves unencrypted data from Kinesis Data Streams and leaks it to external parties, causing a significant data breach.
  3. Exploitation of Misconfigurations: A developer accidentally misconfigures access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access unencrypted data in Kinesis Data Streams. Attackers exploit this vulnerability to extract sensitive information.

By implementing these strategies, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with unencrypted data at rest in AWS Kinesis Data Streams, ensuring the protection of sensitive information and compliance with security best practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Lack of API call monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Lack of API Call Monitoring in AWS Kinesis Data Streams refers to the absence of oversight and tracking of API calls made to the service. Without proper monitoring, unauthorized or malicious activities may go undetected, leading to potential security breaches, data loss, and operational disruptions. Continuous monitoring of API calls is crucial for detecting suspicious activities and ensuring compliance with security policies.

Threat Agents:

  • External attackers exploiting unmonitored API calls.
  • Malicious insiders performing unauthorized actions.
  • Compromised accounts used to execute unauthorized API calls.

Attack Vectors:

  • Unauthorized API calls using stolen or compromised credentials.
  • Insiders abusing their access rights to make unauthorized changes.
  • Automated scripts or bots making excessive or unauthorized API requests.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access and actions can lead to data breaches and leakage of sensitive information.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious API calls can disrupt the normal operation of Kinesis Data Streams, leading to downtime and loss of productivity.
  • Compliance Violations: Lack of monitoring can result in non-compliance with industry regulations and standards, attracting legal penalties.
  • Reputation Damage: Security incidents arising from unmonitored API calls can erode customer trust and damage the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Data Access: An attacker gains access to AWS credentials through a phishing attack. Without API call monitoring, the attacker makes unauthorized API calls to Kinesis Data Streams, exfiltrating sensitive data without detection.
  2. Insider Threat: A disgruntled employee uses their access rights to perform unauthorized API actions, such as deleting data streams or modifying configurations, causing significant operational disruptions.
  3. Automated Bot Attack: A botnet performs a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack by making excessive API requests to Kinesis Data Streams, overwhelming the service and causing a denial of service for legitimate users. Without monitoring, the attack goes undetected until service disruptions occur.

By implementing these mitigation strategies, organizations can ensure comprehensive monitoring of API calls to AWS Kinesis Data Streams, enhancing security and reducing the risk of unauthorized actions going undetected.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed logging
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance visibility into data access and modifications within AWS Lake Formation, it is essential to enable detailed logging of Lake Formation activities. These logs help monitor and audit various actions performed in the data lake, ensuring that any unauthorized access or changes are promptly identified and addressed.

Here's a step-by-step guide to implement detailed logging for Lake Formation:

  1. Enable AWS CloudTrail: Ensure that AWS CloudTrail is enabled in your account. CloudTrail tracks API calls made to AWS Lake Formation, recording information such as the identity of the caller, the time of the call, and the details of the API request. For instructions on enabling CloudTrail, refer to the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.
  2. Configure AWS Config Rules: Set up AWS Config rules to monitor compliance with best security practices in AWS Lake Formation. AWS Config can continuously assess whether your resources and their configurations comply with the configurations that you specify. See more about AWS Config in the AWS Config Developer Guide.
  3. Define Logging and Monitoring Policies: Establish policies for what specific activities need to be logged and monitored. This includes defining which Lake Formation actions and resources should trigger logging events. For a comprehensive list of Lake Formation actions that can be logged, refer to the Lake Formation Logging and Monitoring guide.
  4. Store and Analyze Logs: Utilize Amazon S3 to store the logs generated by CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch Logs for real-time monitoring and analysis. You can set up CloudWatch Alarms for automated notifications based on log queries and metrics.
  5. Review and Audit Logs Regularly: Regularly review the logs to identify any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts. Periodic auditing ensures that your security policies and controls are effective. Detailed information on how to audit AWS Lake Formation activities can be found in the AWS Lake Formation Security Guidelines.

Implementing these measures ensures that you have robust logging and monitoring in place for AWS Lake Formation, enhancing your ability to maintain data security and integrity. For further details on security best practices for AWS Lake Formation, refer to the AWS Documentation on Security in Lake Formation.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that all data stored in AWS Lake Formation is encrypted at rest using AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS), follow the security best practices as outlined in the AWS Lake Formation documentation.

Step-by-Step Guidance:

  1. Create a Key in AWS KMS: First, you need to create a Customer Managed Key (CMK) in AWS KMS. Navigate to the AWS KMS console, choose Customer managed keys, and then click Create key. Follow the wizard and configure the key policy to ensure appropriate access permissions are set.

    For more details, refer to the AWS KMS Documentation.

  2. Configure Data Lake Settings: In the AWS Lake Formation console, go to the Data Lake Settings. Under the Encryption section, select Default encryption for data stores. Choose Enable encryption and select the Customer Managed Key (CMK) created in AWS KMS.

    Refer to the Encryption at Rest documentation for additional details.

  3. Encrypt Data: When you create or register new data locations, ensure that the encryption settings are properly configured to use the specified KMS key. AWS Lake Formation will automatically encrypt the data at rest using the provided KMS key.

  4. Verify Encryption Status: Periodically verify the encryption status of your data. You can do this by accessing the AWS Lake Formation console and reviewing the properties of your data lake locations to ensure that encryption is enabled and using the correct KMS key.

References:

  • AWS Lake Formation - Encryption at Rest
  • AWS KMS - Creating Keys
  • AWS Lake Formation - Data Encryption

countermeasure.name: Use SourceArn and SourceAccount to restrict AWS Lake Formation permissions
countermeasure.desc:
To mitigate the risk of cross-service confused deputy attacks in AWS Lake Formation, it is crucial to restrict permissions to specific trusted accounts and resources. This can be accomplished by leveraging the SourceArn and SourceAccount global condition context keys. By using these keys, you can ensure that AWS Lake Formation interactions are only permitted from specified sources, thereby reducing the risk of unauthorized access. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Identify the ARNs of the resources and AWS accounts that require access to AWS Lake Formation. Document these ARNs for use in your policy.
  2. Navigate to the AWS IAM console and access the policy editor to create or modify the IAM policies related to AWS Lake Formation.
  3. Within the policy, add conditions using the SourceArn and SourceAccount condition keys to restrict access. For example: 
    
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": ["lakeformation:*"],
    "Resource": "*",
    "Condition": {
      "StringEquals": {
        "aws:SourceAccount": "123456789012"
      },
      "StringLike": {
        "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:s3:::example-bucket/*"
      }
    }
  }
}
  4. Review the policy to ensure it correctly covers all required entities and does not inadvertently grant broader access.
  5. Apply the policy to the relevant IAM roles or users who will be interacting with AWS Lake Formation.
  6. Test the policy to verify that permissions work as expected and that access is denied when attempted from unauthorized accounts or resources.

For further details on preventing cross-service confused deputy attacks and using global condition context keys, refer to the AWS Lake Formation documentation on Cross-Service Confused Deputy Prevention.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Cross-service confused deputy
threat.desc:
General threat description
In a cross-service confused deputy attack, an attacker uses a less-privileged service to perform actions on behalf of a highly privileged service, leading to potential unauthorized access and actions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers exploit weaknesses in inter-service trust and permission models to manipulate less-privileged services into making requests on behalf of highly privileged services.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data, execution of unauthorized actions, and potential compromise of the entire AWS Lake Formation environment.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker compromises a read-only data processing service and manipulates it to escalate privileges and gain access to the data catalog, allowing them to read or alter sensitive information in the data lake.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure data storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing sensitive data without proper encryption measures can result in data being exposed to unauthorized users. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit misconfigured AWS Lake Formation settings or vulnerabilities to access unencrypted sensitive data, or insiders with unauthorized access may misuse their privileges. 
Impacts
Potential loss of confidential information, financial loss, reputational damage, and regulatory penalties. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS Lake Formation due to improperly set permissions and accesses unencrypted sensitive data, resulting in a data breach. Alternatively, an insider with elevated privileges extracts and misuses unencrypted sensitive information for personal gain.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring of access and activity
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of adequate monitoring and auditing mechanisms can significantly weaken the ability to detect unauthorized access or suspicious activities within AWS Lake Formation environments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or external attackers who exploit the absence of real-time monitoring and auditing to gain or maintain access to sensitive data undetected.
Impacts
Potential unauthorized data access, data leakage, data modification, and compliance violations; delayed incident response and extended recovery times.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to Lake Formation resources and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to the lack of monitoring and auditing, the unauthorized access goes unnoticed until the damage is already done. Another scenario involves an insider who continually accesses restricted datasets without any detection, potentially leaking confidential information to external parties.

weakness.name: CWE-1047
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1047: Modules with Circular Dependencies The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

weakness.name: CWE-1193
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1193: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-312
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-416
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-416: Use After Free Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-672
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-672: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply permission boundaries to cap Lambda role and user privileges
countermeasure.desc:
Define a single IAM permission-boundary policy that represents the maximum set of actions a Lambda workload should ever performtypically the core lambda:*, CloudWatch Logs calls, and tightly scoped access to specific AWS resources. Attach that boundary to:

  • Every Lambda execution role (via the PermissionBoundary property in CloudFormation/Terraform).
  • All human or CI/CD principals that can create or update functions.

Because AWS evaluates the boundary before attached or inline policies, anything not explicitly allowed by the boundary is automatically deniedeven if someone tries to grant broader rights later.

quick implementation

  1. Author and publish the boundary
    1. {
       "Version":"2012-10-17",
       "Statement":[
         { "Effect":"Allow", "Action":[
             "lambda:*",
             "logs:CreateLogGroup", "logs:CreateLogStream", "logs:PutLogEvents"
           ], "Resource":"*" },
         { "Effect":"Deny", "Action":[ "iam:*", "organizations:*", "lambda:DeleteFunction" ], "Resource":"*" }
       ]
      }
       
    2. aws iam create-policy --policy-name lambda-boundary --policy-document file://boundary.json
  2. Attach the boundary
    1. aws iam put-role-permissions-boundary \
          --role-name OrderProcessorRole \
          --permissions-boundary arn:aws:iam::<acct>:policy/lambda-boundary
  3. Enforce automatically
    • Add a pipeline check (e.g., cfn-lint, Checkov) that fails if a new role lacks PermissionBoundary.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-permissions-boundary-check and create a similar custom rule for roles to detect drift.
  4. Maintain
    Review the boundary every quarter: remove unused Allow actions, add new ones only after peer approval, and keep the policy version history in source control.

References

  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities
  • Lambda security best practices IAM boundaries

countermeasure.name: Deploy VPC Lambda functions across multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
For every Lambda function that runs inside a VPC, attach at least two private subnets that reside in different Availability Zones (AZs). Lambda automatically spreads function instances across all subnets you specify, so providing subnets in multiple AZs gives the function resiliency against an AZ-level failure.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet planning In the target VPC, create two or more /24 (or smaller) private subnets, each located in a distinct AZ (for example, subnet-az1a-private, subnet-az1b-private). If the function needs outbound internet access, give every AZ its own NAT gateway or egress path.
  2. Configure the function
    • Console: Configuration VPC Edit select the VPC and tick both (or all) private subnets.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
      • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
         --function-name order-processor \
         --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0a12,subnet-0b34,SecurityGroupIds=sg-0abc
  3. Security groups Attach a least-privilege security group that allows only the ports and CIDRs the function truly needs (for example, TCP 5432 to an RDS cluster SG).
  4. Guardrails Implement an AWS Config custom rule or cfn-nag check that fails a deployment when a VPC-connected Lambda lists fewer than two subnets.
  5. Validation & monitoring Use the Lambda consoles Monitoring Subnet metrics or CloudWatchs Duration metrics to confirm invocations appear from each AZ. Include a canary test that fires if an AZs invocations drop to zero.

Spreading subnets across Availability Zones ensures the function continues to invoke even if one AZor its networking componentsbecomes unavailable.

References

  • AWS Lambda resilience guidance
  • Create more than one subnet across different AZ

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Lambda env vars and code artifacts with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Safeguard every sensitive value that AWS Lambda storesenvironment variables, .zip deployment packages, container images, and event-filter criteriaby encrypting them with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of the default AWS-managed key. Using your own CMK lets you control key rotation, scope decrypt permissions tightly, and audit every use.

1 . Create or choose a CMK

aws kms create-key --description "Lambda data-at-rest CMK"
aws kms enable-key-rotation --key-id <key-id>

Limit the key policy to the Lambda service principal and the minimal set of roles that need kms:Decrypt / kms:GenerateDataKey.

2 . Encrypt environment variables

  • Console / IaC: set the KMS key ARN field (CloudFormation KmsKeyArn, Terraform kms_key_arn).
  • CLI:
    • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
          --function-name order-processor \
          --kms-key-arn arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd

Lambda now uses your CMK to encrypt Env Vars and event-filter JSON.

3 . Protect deployment artifacts

  • .zip packages in S3 store them in a bucket with SSE-KMS and the same CMK:
    • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
          --bucket lambda-artifacts-prod \
          --server-side-encryption-configuration \
          '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":
             {"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/lambda-data"}}]}'
  • Container images in ECR ensure the ECR repository uses KMS encryption with your CMK.

4 . Grant least-privilege KMS access

Add this statement (scoped to the CMK ARN) to the functions execution role:

{
 "Effect": "Allow",
 "Action": [
   "kms:Decrypt",
   "kms:GenerateDataKey*"
 ],
 "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd"
}

5 . Continuous assurance

  • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-env-vars-encrypted (or a custom rule) to flag functions without a CMK.
  • Create CloudWatch alarms on KMS metric NumberOfFailedDecryptRequests.
  • Rotate the CMK annually; update KmsKeyArn in templates, then disable the old key after confirming no decrypt errors.

Encrypting Lambda data with your own KMS keys gives you full custody of cryptographic material, meets stringent compliance mandates, and lets you trace every decrypt back to an invoking principal.

References

  • Encrypting environment variables and artifacts with a customer-managed KMS key
  • Using AWS KMS keys with AWS Lambda

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enforce bootstrap-aware CI/CD reviews and linting
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the security countermeasure that safeguards AWS Lambda custom runtimes by treating 'bootstrap' and Lambda runtime layers as sensitive code, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Establish a Peer Review Process:
    • Define a policy that mandates peer reviews for any changes to files named 'bootstrap' or runtime layers containing 'bootstrap'.
    • Implement a system in your version control platform (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket) that explicitly requires an "approval" label before merging code involving these sensitive components.
    • Ensure that reviewers are experienced in security practices and familiar with Lambda runtimes.
  2. Deploy Static Code Analysis Tools:
    • Integrate static analysis tools (e.g., Checkmarx, SonarQube) into the CI/CD pipeline.
    • Configure these tools to flag and fail builds when detected risky constructs such as:
      • curl, wget, or nc
      • Any usage of bash -c
      • Unchecked or blind network egress calls
    • Introduce an allowlist mechanism where risky constructs can only bypass checks if accompanied by a written, justified reason reviewed and approved by security teams.
  3. Restrict Bootstrap Role:
    • Verify that the 'bootstrap' file solely performs runtime initialization tasks and invokes the handler or Runtime Interface Client (RIC) as designed.
    • Apply rules to forbid any embedded persistence, telemetry beacons, or additional functionality within the 'bootstrap', unless explicitly approved through the peer-review process.
    • Audit the 'bootstrap' code periodically to ensure compliance with these restrictions.
  4. Enforce Pipeline-Only Deployment:
    • Block any direct uploads of Lambda runtime layers or the 'bootstrap' file via the AWS Management Console.
    • Configure permissions so that developers can only deploy changes through a CI/CD pipeline that enforces defined security checks.
    • Apply IAM policies to prevent unauthorized access to runtime layer modification workflows.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Official Documentation
  • AWS CodePipeline Documentation
  • AWS Security Blog
