usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Exploitation of CRM accounts and integrations
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers may exploit weak access controls, insecure integrations, or compromised credentials to gain unauthorized access, manipulate data, elevate privileges, or steal sensitive customer information from the CRM system.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Insider threats, phishing attacks, brute force attempts, exploitation of third-party integration vulnerabilities, and misuse of stolen login credentials.
Impacts
Loss of customer trust, legal penalties, financial losses, reputational damage, and operational disruption within the call center.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker bypasses poorly implemented access permissions to modify customer account settings; or uses compromised credentials obtained via phishing to extract sensitive customer data from the system that could later be sold or exploited.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Credential compromise and data disclosure
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to the CRM system caused by credential theft or social engineering can result in data tampering or the leakage of sensitive customer information via cases, chats, or portals.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may use phishing, impersonation, or other social engineering techniques to obtain credentials or exploit weak authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access.
Impacts
Compromise of customer trust due to exposure of sensitive information, potential legal or regulatory penalties, and operational disruptions within the call center.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious actor sends a convincing phishing email posing as IT support, tricking a call center employee into revealing their CRM login credentials. The attacker then accesses the CRM, alters customer data, and exports sensitive information for nefarious purposes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Operational disruption and repudiation
threat.desc:
General threat description
Adversaries may exploit call centers by overwhelming them with fraudulent requests, obstructing legitimate users from accessing support services, or disputing completed actions if audit logging is inadequate.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can use automated systems or teams of individuals to flood call centers with fake queries, leverage gaps in authentication protocols, or exploit insufficient monitoring and logging mechanisms.
Impacts
Legitimate customers may face delays or denial of service, reputational damage to the organization may occur, and financial losses might result from fraudulent claims and actions that cannot be contested due to auditing deficiencies.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker consistently places automated calls to the call center, causing long queues that prevent real customers from seeking help. Alternatively, a fraudster calls to make unauthorized account changes and later denies involvement because audit trails are incomplete, making their repudiation hard to disprove.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Social engineering against call center agents
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers may impersonate administrators or users by employing phishing or vishing techniques to deceive call center agents into performing unauthorized actions, such as resetting multi-factor authentication, modifying authentication factors, or granting access without verification.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors who use social engineering tactics, such as phishing emails or vishing calls, to manipulate call center personnel.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive accounts or systems, loss of data integrity, potential financial fraud, and erosion of trust in the organizations security practices.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker poses as a legitimate user claiming to have lost access to an account and convinces the call center agent to reset the multi-factor authentication settings without proper verification. Alternatively, the attacker might impersonate an administrator, requesting changes to authentication methods or bypassing security protocols.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-941
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-941: Incorrectly Specified Destination in a Communication Channel The product creates a communication channel to initiate an outgoing request to an actor, but it does not correctly specify the intended destination for that actor.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data in emails to protect it during transmission
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing encryption for sensitive data in emails is a crucial security measure to protect confidentiality and integrity during transmission. Here's how to effectively encrypt sensitive data in emails, tailored for developers:

Choose an Encryption Standard

  1. Select an Encryption Protocol: Use established protocols like S/MIME (Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions) or PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) for email encryption. S/MIME is widely supported by commercial email clients, while PGP is popular in open-source environments.
  2. Obtain Digital Certificates for S/MIME: If using S/MIME, obtain a digital certificate from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA). For each user, you'll need a certificate that includes their public key.

Implement Encryption in the Email Sending Process

  1. Configure Your Email Client or Server: Integrate the chosen encryption protocol into your email client or server. Most email software has support for S/MIME or can use plugins for PGP.
  2. Encrypt the Email Content: Before sending an email containing sensitive data, encrypt the content using the recipient's public key. This ensures that only the recipient, who possesses the corresponding private key, can decrypt and read the email.
  3. Attach the Digital Signature: Attach a digital signature to the email. This signature, created with your private key, allows the recipient to verify the email's authenticity and integrity.

Educate and Support Your Users

  1. Distribute Digital Certificates or Public Keys: Ensure that all users have access to the necessary digital certificates or public keys of their intended recipients. For S/MIME, distribute certificates through a secure channel. For PGP, use a public key server or secure directory.
  2. User Training: Provide training for your users on how to encrypt emails and understand the importance of encryption. Include guidelines on recognizing and handling sensitive data.

Testing and Maintenance

  1. Conduct Regular Audits: Periodically review your email encryption implementation to ensure compliance with security policies and standards. Adjust configurations as necessary to adapt to new threats or changes in technology.
  2. Update and Revocation: Keep your encryption tools and certificates up to date. Have a process in place for revoking and replacing certificates if they are compromised.

Good Security Practices

  • Principle of Least Privilege: Limit access to encryption keys and certificates to only those users and systems that require them.
  • Backup and Recovery: Regularly backup encryption keys and certificates and have a recovery plan in place in case of loss.
  • Compliance: Ensure your encryption practices comply with relevant regulations and industry standards, such as GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS.

By following these steps, developers can implement robust encryption for sensitive data in emails, significantly enhancing the security of email communication within their organization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Implement email authentication standards to verify sender identity
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of a "Send Email" software component by implementing email authentication standards to verify sender identity, follow these actionable steps. These standards include SPF (Sender Policy Framework), DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail), and DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance). Each plays a crucial role in verifying that the sender is who they claim to be, thus helping to prevent email spoofing and phishing attacks.

Step 1: Implement SPF (Sender Policy Framework)

  1. Identify Outgoing Email Servers: List all servers and services that send email on behalf of your domain.
  2. Create an SPF Record: Construct an SPF record in TXT format for your DNS. This record lists all authorized sending servers. For example: "v=spf1 ip4:192.168.0.1 include:_spf.google.com ~all" indicates that emails are sent from the IP address 192.168.0.1 and include Google's SPF records, with a soft fail for others.
  3. Publish the SPF Record: Add the SPF record to your domain's DNS settings. This allows recipient servers to check if incoming emails from your domain are sent from listed servers.

Step 2: Set Up DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail)

  1. Generate DKIM Key Pair: Use a tool or service to generate a public/private key pair for DKIM. Keep the private key secure and use it to sign outgoing emails.
  2. Publish the Public Key: Add your DKIM public key to your domain's DNS records. This is typically done as a TXT record and allows recipient servers to retrieve and use this key to verify the signature of incoming emails.
  3. Configure Email Server to Sign Emails: Adjust your email server's settings to automatically sign all outgoing emails with your DKIM private key. Ensure it signs parts of the email that are unlikely to change in transit.

Step 3: Configure DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance)

  1. Set DMARC Policy: Decide on a DMARC policy for your domain, indicating how receivers should handle emails that dont pass SPF or DKIM checks (e.g., none, quarantine, reject).
  2. Create DMARC Record: Construct a DMARC TXT record for your DNS. For example: "v=DMARC1; p=reject; rua=mailto:dmarc-reports@example.com" specifies a reject policy and where to send aggregate reports.
  3. Publish DMARC Record: Add the DMARC record to your domain's DNS settings, similar to SPF and DKIM records.

Good Security Practices

  • Regularly Update Records: Keep your SPF, DKIM, and DMARC records up to date, especially if you change email service providers or add new email servers.
  • Monitor Reports: Regularly review DMARC reports to identify and address unauthorized use of your domain.
  • Test Configuration: Use tools to test and verify the correctness of your SPF, DKIM, and DMARC setup. Tools like mxtoolbox.com or dmarcian.com can validate your configuration.
  • Educate Your Team: Make sure your team understands the importance of these settings to prevent spoofing and ensure email authenticity.

Implementing these email authentication standards is a critical step in securing email communications by verifying sender identity, reducing the likelihood of email-based attacks, and increasing the overall trust in your email ecosystem.

countermeasure.name: Sanitize all input to avoid injection attacks
countermeasure.desc:
Sanitizing input is a fundamental security practice to protect your application from injection attacks, such as SQL Injection, Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), and Command Injection. These steps are designed to be actionable for developers, even those without prior security experience:

Understand Your Data

  1. Identify Data Sources: Recognize all the sources from which your application receives data. This includes user input from forms, URL parameters, API requests, and any external data sources.
  2. Classify Data: Understand the type of data (e.g., text, numbers, dates) expected from each source and what is considered safe or unsafe within the context of your application.

Implement Input Validation

  1. Use Whitelisting: Prefer to validate input against a whitelist of acceptable values or patterns. For example, if you expect a numerical ID, ensure the input is a number within a valid range.
  2. Employ Regular Expressions: Use regular expressions to validate formats, such as email addresses or phone numbers, rejecting any inputs that do not match.
  3. Length and Type Checks: Verify that the input length is within expected bounds. Ensure the data type matches what's expected (e.g., strings for names, integers for ages).

Sanitize Data

  1. Escape Special Characters: Before using input in SQL queries, HTML content, or command lines, escape special characters to prevent interpretation as code or query syntax. Use library functions designed for this purpose, like htmlentities() in PHP for HTML content or parameterized queries for SQL.
  2. Strip Unnecessary Data: Remove any data from the input that is not absolutely necessary for its intended purpose, such as HTML tags in a plain text field.
  3. Use Secure Libraries and Frameworks: Leverage libraries and frameworks that automatically handle input sanitization for you. For web applications, frameworks like OWASP ESAPI, Microsoft's AntiXSS Library, or ORM libraries for SQL can abstract much of the sanitization work.

Design Secure Applications

  1. Principle of Least Privilege: Ensure that the database user your application uses to query the database has only the permissions necessary to perform its functions.
  2. Prepare Statements and Parameterized Queries: Always use prepared statements and parameterized queries when accessing databases to avoid SQL Injection.
  3. Content Security Policy (CSP): Implement CSP in web applications to reduce the risk of XSS by specifying trusted sources for content like scripts, styles, and images.

Educate and Enforce

  1. Security Training: Provide training for developers on secure coding practices, emphasizing the importance of input validation and sanitization.
  2. Code Reviews: Implement a process for security-focused code reviews, checking specifically for input validation and sanitization practices.
  3. Automated Security Scanning: Use automated tools to scan your codebase and dependencies for known vulnerabilities and insecure coding patterns regularly.

By systematically applying these steps, developers can significantly mitigate the risk of injection attacks, protecting both the application and its data from unauthorized access or manipulation.

countermeasure.name: Use content security policy headers to protect against XSS
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Content Security Policy (CSP) headers is a powerful way to protect your web applications, including those involved in sending emails, from Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. CSP provides an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including XSS and data injection attacks. Here's how to implement CSP headers effectively:

Step 1: Understand Your Web Application

  1. Audit Your Resources: Identify all the sources from which your application loads resources. This includes scripts, stylesheets, images, fonts, and any third-party content.
  2. Determine Policy Directives: Based on your audit, determine the appropriate CSP directives that match your application's needs. Common directives include default-src, script-src, style-src, and img-src.

Step 2: Craft Your CSP Policy

  1. Create a Basic Policy: Start with a strict policy that only allows script execution from your own domain. For example, Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; ensures that all content must come from the same origin.
  2. Refine Your Policy: Add additional sources as needed by specifying them in the appropriate directives. For instance, to allow scripts from your domain and a trusted CDN, you might add: script-src 'self' https://cdn.example.com;.
  3. Include Nonce or Hashes: To allow inline scripts or styles, use nonces (a unique token per page load) or hashes to specify allowed content, making it harder for attackers to inject malicious scripts.

Step 3: Implement CSP Headers

  1. Configure Web Server: Add the CSP header to your web server's configuration so it's included with every response. This process varies by server software (Apache, Nginx, IIS, etc.).
    • For Apache, use Header set Content-Security-Policy "your_policy_here"; in your .htaccess or site configuration.
    • For Nginx, add add_header Content-Security-Policy "your_policy_here"; to your server block.
  2. Use Meta Tags: As an alternative or in addition, implement the CSP policy via a <meta> tag in the HTML <head> of your pages, though this method has some limitations compared to HTTP headers.

Step 4: Test and Monitor

  1. Use Report-Only Mode: Initially, set your policy in report-only mode (Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only) to observe potential impacts without affecting users. This lets you collect reports on violations without blocking them.
  2. Analyze Reports: Collect and analyze violation reports to adjust your policy as needed. Set up a reporting URL in your CSP policy with report-uri or the newer report-to directive.
  3. Iterate and Update: Policies may need updates as your web application evolves. Regularly review your CSP policy in conjunction with changes to your application or its content sources.

Good Security Practices

  • Regularly Review Policies: As you add new resources or change existing ones, update your CSP policy to reflect these changes.
  • Minimize Use of unsafe-inline and unsafe-eval: These significantly reduce the effectiveness of CSP against XSS. Aim to eliminate their need through nonces, hashes, or restructuring how scripts are loaded.
  • Educate Your Team: Make sure developers understand CSP and its benefits, and integrate CSP policy updates into your development workflow.

Implementing CSP headers is an ongoing process that enhances your application's security posture. It's not a one-time setup but rather a component of your continuous security improvement practices.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of exposed sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

In the context of email communications, exposed sensitive data refers to any confidential, private, or proprietary information that is not properly secured and thus becomes accessible to unauthorized individuals. This exposure can occur through various means, such as misconfigured email servers, unencrypted emails, or phishing attacks leading to compromised accounts. Once attackers gain access to this sensitive data, they can exploit it for financial gain, identity theft, corporate espionage, or other malicious purposes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  1. Cybercriminals: Individuals or groups looking to exploit exposed data for financial gain, blackmail, or reputation damage.
  2. Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with legitimate access who intentionally or accidentally expose sensitive information.
  3. Competitors: Businesses seeking a competitive advantage may engage in corporate espionage to steal sensitive data.
  4. State-Sponsored Actors: Governments or their proxies might target sensitive data to further national interests.

Attack Vectors include:

  • Phishing Attacks: Deceptive emails that trick recipients into revealing sensitive information.
  • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attacks: Interception of unencrypted emails during transmission.
  • Misconfigured Email Servers: Incorrectly configured servers can expose emails to unauthorized access.
  • Compromised Email Accounts: Accounts breached through various methods can give attackers access to stored emails.

Impacts

  1. Financial Losses: Direct financial theft, costs associated with breach mitigation, and potential fines for regulatory non-compliance.
  2. Reputational Damage: Loss of trust from customers, partners, and the public, leading to a decline in business.
  3. Legal and Regulatory Consequences: Penalties for failing to protect sensitive data as required by laws like GDPR, HIPAA, etc.
  4. Operational Disruption: Time and resources diverted to respond to incidents may impact normal business operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker conducts a phishing campaign against employees of a company. A recipient clicks on a malicious link, which leads to the installation of malware that captures and sends sensitive emails to the attacker.

Scenario 2: A cybercriminal discovers a misconfigured email server that is not properly encrypting data in transit. The attacker exploits this weakness to intercept sensitive emails containing financial information, leading to unauthorized transactions.

Scenario 3: An insider threat, such as a disgruntled employee, intentionally forwards confidential company emails to a competitor or publishes them online, aiming to harm the companys reputation and competitive standing.

This threat underscores the critical importance of securing email communications and implementing best practices for data protection, including the use of encryption, secure email gateways, employee awareness training, and regular audits of email security configurations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1074 - Data Staged||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1114 - Email Collection

threat.name: Attackers leverage cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

In the context of an email application, attackers leveraging XSS vulnerabilities might exploit the application's handling of HTML content in emails. If the application fails to properly sanitize input or email content, malicious scripts embedded in an email could be executed when viewed by the recipient. This could lead to unauthorized access to the recipient's email account, theft of sensitive information, or other malicious activities performed on behalf of the user within the email application or webmail interface.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Phishing Emails: Attackers could send emails containing malicious scripts disguised within seemingly harmless links or embedded directly into the email HTML.
  • Compromised Accounts: An attacker with access to an email account could send emails containing XSS payloads to exploit vulnerabilities in the email client or webmail application of recipients.
  • Third-Party Integrations: External services integrated with the email application, such as file sharing or social media links, could be leveraged to introduce XSS payloads.

Impacts

  • Session Hijacking: An attacker could capture session tokens or cookies, allowing unauthorized access to the victim's email account.
  • Data Theft: Sensitive information accessible through the email client, including personal data and confidential communication, could be exfiltrated.
  • Account Takeover: By exploiting XSS vulnerabilities, attackers might change account settings, steal credentials, or lock legitimate users out of their accounts.
  • Spreading Malware: XSS vulnerabilities could be used to spread malware through email by automatically downloading malicious files when an email is viewed.

Example Attack Scenarios

Embedded Scripts in Email: An attacker sends a targeted phishing email to users of a vulnerable email application. The email contains a malicious script embedded within an HTML image tag. When the recipient opens the email, the script executes, stealing their session cookie and sending it back to the attacker.

Malicious Links: An email crafted by an attacker includes a link that appears legitimate but contains JavaScript code in the URL. When a user clicks on the link, the code executes within the context of the email application, allowing the attacker to perform actions on behalf of the user.

Auto-Executing Attachments: An attacker sends an email with an HTML attachment designed to automatically execute JavaScript when viewed. The script in the attachment redirects the user to a malicious site or downloads malware onto their device.

To mitigate these risks, email applications should:

  • Sanitize Input: Ensure that all incoming email content, including HTML and URLs, is properly sanitized to remove or neutralize potentially malicious code.
  • Content Security Policy (CSP): Implement CSP headers to prevent the execution of unauthorized scripts.
  • User Education: Educate users on the risks of clicking on unknown links or opening attachments from untrusted sources.
  • Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security assessments of the email application to identify and remediate potential vulnerabilities.

Addressing XSS vulnerabilities in email applications requires a multi-faceted approach, combining technical safeguards with user education and awareness to protect against these threats.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers attempt to spoof email sender addresses to impersonate legitimate users
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Email spoofing involves forging the sender's address in an email message to make it appear as though it comes from someone else, typically a trusted individual or organization. This technique is often used in phishing attacks and scam attempts to deceive recipients into divulging sensitive information, executing unauthorized transactions, or downloading malware. The simplicity of SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol), which lacks authentication mechanisms in its core specifications, facilitates this type of attack.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Phishers and Scammers: Individuals or groups aiming to deceive recipients for financial gain, data theft, or to deploy malware.
  • Business Email Compromise (BEC) Attackers: These attackers specialize in crafting emails that appear to come from high-ranking officials within an organization to manipulate employees into transferring funds or sensitive data.
  • Spammers: Utilize spoofing to bypass email filters, spreading unsolicited and potentially malicious content.

Impacts

  • Financial Loss: Victims may be tricked into making payments to fraudulent accounts.
  • Data Breach: Sensitive information may be disclosed to unauthorized parties.
  • Malware Infection: Malicious attachments or links within spoofed emails can lead to malware infections.
  • Reputation Damage: Impersonation of individuals or organizations can damage their reputation and erode trust among clients or colleagues.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CEO Fraud: An attacker spoofs the email address of a company's CEO and sends an urgent request to the finance department to wire funds to an external account, claiming it's for a confidential deal.
  2. Impersonation of a Trusted Organization: An attacker sends an email that appears to be from a well-known service provider, asking recipients to reset their passwords. The link in the email redirects to a phishing site designed to steal credentials.
  3. Fake Invoice: A supplier's email address is spoofed to send a fake invoice to a company. The email instructs payment to a new account, which is controlled by the attacker.

To mitigate the risks of email spoofing:

  • Implement Email Authentication Protocols: Use SPF (Sender Policy Framework), DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail), and DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance) to authenticate outgoing emails and verify incoming emails. These protocols help to ensure that the sender is authorized by the domain owner and that the email has not been altered in transit.
  • Educate Users: Train employees to recognize signs of phishing and spoofed emails, such as checking for subtle misspellings in the sender's address, scrutinizing the email content for unusual requests, and verifying the email's legitimacy through other communication channels.
  • Use Email Filtering Solutions: Deploy advanced email security solutions that can detect spoofing attempts, filter out phishing emails, and block known malicious domains.
  • Encourage Secure Communication Practices: For sensitive transactions, encourage the use of secure, authenticated communication channels outside of email.

Addressing email spoofing requires a combination of technical solutions and user awareness to effectively reduce the threat and protect against potential financial, data, and reputational losses.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1566 - Phishing||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code injection attacks involve the introduction of malicious code into a software system, exploiting security vulnerabilities such as input validation flaws, outdated software components, or misconfigurations. The injected code can be executed by the system, leading to unauthorized access, data breaches, and a variety of other malicious outcomes. Email systems, due to their accessibility and the sensitive nature of the data they handle, can be particularly vulnerable to such attacks, which may target servers, client applications, or associated web interfaces.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  1. Cybercriminals: Seek financial gain or personal satisfaction from disrupting systems and stealing data.
  2. Hacktivists: Aim to promote political agendas or social causes by attacking high-profile targets.
  3. State-Sponsored Actors: Engage in espionage or sabotage against organizations or governments.
  4. Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with access who intentionally or inadvertently facilitate these attacks.

Attack Vectors include:

  • Email Attachments: Malicious code hidden in files that execute when opened by the recipient.
  • Phishing Links: URLs leading to websites that exploit browser vulnerabilities to execute code.
  • Input Fields on Web Interfaces: Unsanitized inputs that allow script injection into web pages or backend systems.
  • Third-party Integrations: Exploiting vulnerabilities in software that interacts with the email system.

Impacts

  1. Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain control over email systems, leading to data theft and surveillance.
  2. Data Breach: Sensitive information is compromised, affecting users and related parties.
  3. System Compromise: Malicious code can spread to interconnected systems, amplifying the damage.
  4. Reputational Damage: Loss of trust from users and stakeholders, with long-term implications for the organization.
  5. Legal and Financial Consequences: Costs associated with incident response, potential fines, and litigation.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker crafts a phishing email containing a malicious attachment. When an employee opens the attachment, the malicious code exploits a vulnerability in the email client to install malware on the system, giving the attacker remote access.

Scenario 2: A web-based email service has a vulnerability in its input validation process. An attacker sends an email containing a script as part of the message body. When the email is opened, the script executes within the email server environment, allowing the attacker to extract user data.

Scenario 3: An organization fails to update its email system, leaving known vulnerabilities unpatched. Attackers exploit one such vulnerability to inject a ransomware payload through a crafted email, encrypting the organization's data and demanding payment for its release.

Protecting against code injection requires a multifaceted approach, including regular software updates, rigorous input validation, the principle of least privilege, and user education to recognize and avoid phishing attempts. Additionally, deploying intrusion detection systems and conducting regular security audits can help identify and mitigate vulnerabilities before they can be exploited.

weakness.name: CWE-1122
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1122: Excessive Halstead Complexity The code is structured in a way that a Halstead complexity measure exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-926
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-926: Improper Export of Android Application Components The Android application exports a component for use by other applications, but does not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains.

countermeasure.name: Configure automatic mobile OS updates
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update automatic mobile OS updates on all mobile devices to ensure they are running the latest secure versions of their operating systems. This control minimizes exposure to vulnerabilities by promptly applying critical patches and security improvements as they are released. Developers and DevOps engineers should configure mobile device management (MDM) solutions or native OS settings to enforce automatic updates and continuously monitor update compliance across the device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Auto-Updates:
Configure mobile devices to automatically download and install OS updates as soon as they are available.

Deploy Centralized Update Policies:
Use MDM solutions to enforce and manage update policies across all mobile devices, ensuring uniform compliance.

Monitor Update Compliance:
Regularly audit update logs and compliance reports to verify that all devices are running the latest OS versions and apply remediation if discrepancies are found.

References:

  • Android Enterprise Updates

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Deploy mobile anti-malware solutions
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update mobile anti-malware solutions on all mobile devices to detect, prevent, and remediate malware infections that could compromise the device's security. This control ensures that reputable anti-malware software with real-time scanning and periodic full-device scans is installed and maintained. Developers and DevOps engineers should use mobile device management (MDM) tools to enforce consistent deployment, configuration, and automatic updates of malware definitions across the entire mobile device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Install Reputable Anti-Malware Software:
Deploy trusted anti-malware applications on all mobile devices via MDM solutions or approved installation packages.

Enable Real-Time Scanning:
Configure the anti-malware solution to continuously monitor device activity and block potential threats in real time.

Schedule Regular Full-Device Scans:
Set up periodic scans to identify and remediate any dormant or emerging malware infections.

Automate Malware Definition Updates:
Ensure the anti-malware software is configured to automatically update its threat definitions to keep pace with emerging threats.

Monitor and Audit Compliance:
Use centralized management tools to verify that all devices maintain up-to-date anti-malware protection and address any compliance issues promptly.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-83: Guide to Malware Incident Prevention and Handling

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Deploy mobile anti-phishing protection
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update anti-phishing protection on all mobile devices to detect and block phishing attempts targeting mobile users. This control leverages built-in email and browser security features, integrates threat intelligence feeds, and enforces centralized policies to ensure that phishing attacks are promptly identified and mitigated. Developers and DevOps engineers should use mobile device management (MDM) solutions to deploy and monitor anti-phishing configurations consistently across the entire mobile device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Built-In Anti-Phishing Features:
Activate anti-phishing functionalities available in mobile email and browser applications, ensuring they are properly configured to warn users of suspicious links and communications.

Integrate Threat Intelligence Feeds:
Connect to reputable threat intelligence services (e.g., Google Safe Browsing) to keep phishing detection databases current with emerging phishing trends.

Deploy Centralized Policies:
Use MDM tools to enforce uniform anti-phishing configurations and update policies across all mobile devices, ensuring consistent protection.

Conduct Regular Testing:
Periodically simulate phishing attacks and audit mobile device logs to verify the effectiveness of anti-phishing measures and adjust configurations as needed.

References:

  • Google Safe Browsing API

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Enable remote wipe and tracking features
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update remote wipe and tracking features on all mobile devices to protect sensitive data in the event of device loss or theft. This control utilizes mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enable real-time tracking, location monitoring, and the ability to remotely erase data. By ensuring that these features are active and properly configured, organizations can quickly respond to incidents of loss or theft, mitigating the risk of unauthorized data access and reducing overall impact.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Remote Wipe:
Enable and enforce remote wipe capabilities via MDM settings to allow for immediate data erasure when a device is lost or compromised.

Set Up Device Tracking:
Activate tracking and location reporting features on mobile devices to facilitate quick identification and recovery in case of theft.

Establish Incident Response Procedures:
Define and document processes for initiating remote wipe and tracking actions, including regular testing and drills to ensure readiness.

Monitor and Audit Compliance:
Use centralized management tools to verify that remote wipe and tracking features are enabled across all devices and perform periodic audits to ensure their effectiveness.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-124 Revision 1: Guidelines for Managing the Security of Mobile Devices

standard.ref: PR.DS-3: Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition
PR.IP-6: Data is destroyed according to policy
PR.PT-2: Removable media is protected and its use restricted according to policy

countermeasure.name: Enforce app store whitelisting and robust app vetting
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update app store whitelisting and robust app vetting policies on all mobile devices to ensure that only approved and trusted applications are installed. This control helps mitigate the risk of malicious apps by restricting installations to vetted sources and enforcing strict approval processes. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enforce these policies and continuously monitor app installations.

Implementation Steps:

Establish an App Whitelist:
Identify and maintain a list of approved app stores or specific applications that have been thoroughly vetted for security and compliance.

Deploy Centralized App Management:
Utilize MDM solutions to enforce the whitelist across all mobile devices, ensuring that only approved apps can be installed.

Conduct Robust App Vetting:
Evaluate applications for security vulnerabilities, permissions, and overall risk before adding them to the whitelist, and periodically review the approved apps for compliance.

Monitor and Audit App Installations:
Regularly audit mobile devices for unauthorized apps and update the whitelist based on emerging threats and updated security policies.

References:

  • Apple App Store Review Guidelines

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Enforce regular app updates and conduct vulnerability scanning
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update mobile applications along with conducting periodic vulnerability scanning on all mobile devices to ensure that installed apps remain secure and free of known vulnerabilities. This control minimizes the risk of exploitation through outdated or misconfigured applications by automating app updates and integrating vulnerability assessments into the mobile device management process. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage centralized management tools to enforce update policies and deploy vulnerability scanning solutions to identify and remediate security issues in installed apps.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Auto-Updates for Mobile Apps:
Configure mobile devices and app stores to automatically update applications as new, secure versions are released.

Deploy Vulnerability Scanning Tools:
Utilize mobile security tools to conduct regular vulnerability scans on installed applications, identifying potential weaknesses or misconfigurations.

Integrate with Mobile Device Management (MDM):
Use MDM solutions to enforce app update policies and schedule regular vulnerability assessments across all devices.

Monitor, Report, and Remediate:
Establish processes to monitor scan results, report identified vulnerabilities, and quickly remediate issues through updates or configuration changes.

References:

  • OWASP Mobile Security Testing Guide

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
DE.AE-2: Detected events are analyzed to understand attack targets and methods
DE.AE-4: Impact of events is determined
DE.DP-4: Event detection information is communicated
DE.DP-5: Detection processes are continuously improved
ID.AM-5: Resources (e.g., hardware, devices, data, time, personnel, and software) are prioritized based on their classification, criticality, and business value
ID.BE-2: The organization's place in critical infrastructure and its industry sector is identified and communicated

ID.RA-3: Threats, both internal and external, are identified and documented

ID.RA-6: Risk responses are identified and prioritized

countermeasure.name: Implement secure backup and data synchronization protocols
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update secure backup and data synchronization protocols on all mobile devices to protect sensitive data during storage and transit. This control ensures that backup and synchronization processes use strong encryption, secure communication channels, and trusted storage solutions. Developers and DevOps engineers should configure mobile device management (MDM) tools to enforce secure backup settings and continuously monitor synchronization processes for compliance with organizational security policies.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Encrypted Backups:
Configure mobile devices to encrypt data before backup and ensure that backups are stored using strong encryption standards.

Use Secure Synchronization Channels:
Ensure data synchronization occurs over secure channels (e.g., HTTPS/TLS) to prevent interception during transit.

Enforce Backup Policies via MDM:
Leverage MDM solutions to deploy and enforce secure backup and synchronization settings across all mobile devices.

Monitor and Audit Backup Processes:
Regularly review backup logs and synchronization records to verify that data is securely handled and to identify any anomalies.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-111: Guide to Storage Encryption Technologies

ID.AM-6: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for the entire workforce and third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) are established

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1010 - Deploy Compromised Device Detection Method

countermeasure.name: Implement secure data storage and device encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update secure data storage and device encryption on all mobile devices to safeguard sensitive information from unauthorized access. This control ensures that all locally stored data is encrypted using robust encryption standards, protecting it even if the device is lost or stolen. Developers and DevOps engineers should enforce encryption policies via mobile device management (MDM) solutions, configure devices for full-disk encryption, and use secure storage APIs provided by the operating system. Regular audits and updates are essential to ensure compliance and address emerging security threats.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Full-Disk Encryption:
Enable full-disk encryption on all mobile devices to ensure that all data at rest is secured.

Enforce MDM Policies:
Use MDM solutions to deploy and enforce secure encryption settings across the device fleet.

Leverage Secure Storage APIs:
Utilize OS-provided secure storage mechanisms for sensitive data and application credentials.

Manage Encryption Keys Securely:
Implement robust key management practices to protect encryption keys from unauthorized access.

Audit and Monitor Compliance:
Regularly review encryption settings and conduct audits to verify that encryption policies are consistently applied.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-111: Guide to Storage Encryption Technologies

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1009 - Encrypt Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Implement strong device authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update strong device authentication on all mobile devices to ensure that only authorized users can access the device and its sensitive data. This control involves enforcing robust authentication mechanismssuch as multi-factor authentication (MFA), complex passcodes, and biometric verificationto mitigate the risk of unauthorized access. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions and enterprise identity providers to enforce and monitor these authentication policies across all devices.

Implementation Steps:

Enforce Robust Passcode Policies:
Configure devices to require complex passcodes with a minimum length and periodic changes.

Enable Biometric Authentication:
Utilize built-in biometric features (e.g., fingerprint or facial recognition) to add an additional layer of security.

Deploy Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
Integrate MFA for accessing sensitive applications and data on mobile devices.

Integrate with Enterprise Identity Providers:
Use centralized authentication systems via MDM to enforce consistent policies and monitor compliance across the device fleet.

Regularly Audit Authentication Settings:
Conduct periodic reviews and audits to ensure that authentication configurations remain effective and aligned with evolving security requirements.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-63B: Digital Identity Guidelines

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1007 - Caution with Device Administrator Access

countermeasure.name: Use VPN and enforce encrypted communication channels
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update Virtual Private Network (VPN) configurations and enforce encrypted communication channels on all mobile devices to secure data in transit. This control ensures that all network communications are routed through secure tunnels and that robust encryption protocols (e.g., TLS) are applied, protecting against eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions to deploy VPN configurations and enforce encryption standards consistently across the device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Deploy VPN Solutions:
Configure and enforce the use of reputable VPN solutions on all mobile devices to create secure tunnels for network traffic.

Enable Strong Encryption Protocols:
Ensure that both VPN connections and general network communications use the latest approved encryption protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2/1.3).

Centralized Management:
Use MDM solutions to enforce VPN usage and encrypted communication policies across all mobile devices, and monitor compliance regularly.

Test and Audit:
Conduct periodic security audits and penetration testing to validate that VPN and encrypted channels are correctly implemented and functioning as intended.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-52 Revision 2

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in installed apps
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries identifying and exploiting weaknesses in the mobile applications installed on a device. Vulnerabilities may arise from insecure coding practices, outdated libraries, or improper permission configurations, allowing attackers to compromise app functionality and gain unauthorized access to sensitive data stored on the mobile device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious developers or adversaries who modify legitimate applications to include harmful code.
  • Attackers leveraging known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries integrated into mobile apps.
  • Distribution of compromised or counterfeit apps through both official and unofficial app stores.
  • Exploitation of insecure app permissions and data storage practices within vulnerable applications.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal or sensitive data stored by the apps or on the device.
  • Data exfiltration, leading to privacy breaches and potential financial loss.
  • Compromise of device integrity, allowing for further exploitation and lateral movement within networks.
  • Erosion of user trust, resulting in reputational damage for app developers and service providers.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker discovers a buffer overflow vulnerability in a widely used social media app. By exploiting this flaw, the attacker executes malicious code that accesses and exfiltrates the user's contacts and messages.
  • A modified version of a popular banking app is distributed through a third-party app store. Once installed, the malicious app exploits insecure data storage practices to harvest sensitive financial information, which is then sent to the attackers server.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1455 - Exploit Baseband Vulnerability

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Device theft or loss leading to data compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the potential exposure and unauthorized access of sensitive data when a mobile device is lost or stolen. If the device is not secured with proper encryption and access controls, attackers gaining physical access can extract confidential information, leading to significant data breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Opportunistic criminals targeting lost or stolen devices
  • Unauthorized individuals exploiting weak or absent access controls on the device
  • Attackers leveraging physical access to bypass security measures such as screen locks or encryption

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal, financial, or corporate data
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, and further unauthorized activities
  • Potential reputational and financial damage for individuals and organizations

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile device is left unattended in a public place; an opportunistic thief retrieves the device, bypasses its weak screen lock, and accesses stored sensitive data.
  • A stolen mobile device without full-disk encryption allows an attacker to extract confidential business information and personal data, which is then used for further malicious activities.

threat.name: Interception of network communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries intercepting and potentially altering data transmitted between a mobile device and external networks. Attackers exploit insecure or misconfigured network channels to capture sensitive information and may manipulate the data to facilitate further attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals deploying rogue Wi-Fi access points or hotspots
  • Man-in-the-middle attackers exploiting unencrypted network protocols
  • Hackers leveraging vulnerabilities in mobile operating systems or network stacks
  • Adversaries compromising network devices such as routers

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data such as login credentials, financial information, or personal details
  • Data manipulation leading to fraudulent transactions or misinformation
  • Compromised privacy and erosion of user trust in mobile connectivity
  • Increased risk of subsequent targeted attacks due to exposed session data

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile device connects to a public Wi-Fi network, where an attacker uses a rogue access point to intercept and log sensitive communications, capturing login credentials and personal data.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the mobile OS network stack to perform a man-in-the-middle attack, altering data exchanged between the device and a secure server, resulting in unauthorized transactions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1438 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data due to insecure local storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the risk that sensitive data stored locally on mobile devices may be accessible to unauthorized users due to insecure storage practices. Weak local storage mechanisms, such as unencrypted files or poorly secured databases, can expose personal, financial, or corporate data if the device is compromised or accessed by malicious actors.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals targeting unencrypted or misconfigured storage systems on mobile devices
  • Malicious applications that gain access to local storage areas containing sensitive information
  • Attackers leveraging physical access to the device or exploiting vulnerabilities in the operating system to retrieve data
  • Insider threats with legitimate access to the device who misuse stored data

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to and exfiltration of sensitive information
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, or corporate espionage
  • Compromise of user privacy and potential regulatory or legal consequences for organizations
  • Erosion of user trust in the security of mobile applications and services

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in a mobile app that stores user credentials in plain text, allowing them to extract this sensitive information directly from the devices local storage.
  • A lost or stolen device without proper encryption on its local storage is accessed by unauthorized users, leading to the extraction of confidential personal and corporate data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1533 - Data from Local System

threat.name: Data leakage via insecure backup or synchronization services
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the risk that sensitive data stored on mobile devices is exposed through insecure backup or synchronization services. Weaknesses in the configuration or implementation of these services may allow unauthorized access or interception of data during backup or synchronization processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals exploiting misconfigured or unsecured cloud backup services.
  • Attackers intercepting data during transmission between the mobile device and backup servers.
  • Malicious insiders with access to backup systems.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in synchronization protocols or software.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal, corporate, or sensitive data.
  • Data theft, leading to privacy breaches and potential financial or reputational damage.
  • Increased risk of subsequent attacks if leaked data includes authentication credentials or sensitive operational information.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker identifies a misconfigured cloud backup service used by a mobile device client, gaining access to unencrypted backup files containing sensitive user data.
  • A mobile device synchronizes data with a cloud service over an unencrypted connection, allowing a man-in-the-middle attacker to intercept and exfiltrate confidential information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1470 - Obtain Device Cloud Backups

threat.name: Malware infections on the mobile device
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the introduction and execution of malicious software on mobile devices, which can compromise device functionality, steal sensitive data, or provide a foothold for further attacks. Malware can be delivered through various channels, and once installed, it may operate covertly to disrupt services, exfiltrate information, or control the device remotely.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals distributing malicious apps through unofficial app stores or compromised legitimate apps.
  • Phishing campaigns that trick users into downloading malware-laden attachments or links.
  • Drive-by downloads from compromised or malicious websites accessed via the mobile device.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in mobile operating systems and applications to install malware without user consent.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data including personal, financial, or corporate information.
  • Degradation of device performance, data loss, and system instability.
  • Potential for the malware to spread laterally within networks or facilitate further cyberattacks.
  • Loss of user privacy and increased risk of identity theft or financial fraud.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A user installs an app from an unofficial app store that appears legitimate but contains hidden malware, which then records keystrokes and sends sensitive information to a remote attacker.
  • An attacker sends a phishing message with a link to a compromised website; when the user visits the site, a drive-by download installs malware on the device, enabling the attacker to take control of the device remotely.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1473 - Malicious or Vulnerable Built-in Device Functionality

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to weak device authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries exploiting insufficient authentication measures on mobile devices, such as weak PINs, passwords, or absence of biometric verification, to gain unauthorized access. Without robust authentication, attackers can easily bypass device security, potentially accessing sensitive data and applications stored on the device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals using brute force or credential stuffing attacks against weak passwords or PINs.
  • Insider threats or unauthorized individuals exploiting minimal authentication controls on lost or shared devices.
  • Attackers leveraging social engineering tactics to trick users into revealing their authentication credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data stored on the mobile device.
  • Potential for further lateral movement within an organization if the device is connected to corporate networks.
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, and privacy breaches.
  • Compromise of device integrity, leading to installation of malware or unauthorized configuration changes.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a brute force tool to systematically guess a weak 4-digit PIN on a mobile device, eventually gaining access and extracting sensitive information.
  • A lost or unattended mobile device with weak authentication is retrieved by an unauthorized individual who accesses stored emails, contacts, and financial applications, resulting in data theft or misuse.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1626.001 - Device Administrator Permissions

threat.name: Phishing attacks targeting mobile users
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries using deceptive techniques to lure mobile device users into providing sensitive information or downloading malicious content. Phishing attacks on mobile devices often exploit the smaller screen size and limited context to trick users into trusting fraudulent messages, emails, or websites that mimic legitimate services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals employing social engineering tactics via SMS, email, or instant messaging.
  • Malicious websites or in-app advertisements that redirect users to counterfeit login pages.
  • Adversaries using cloned or lookalike mobile apps designed to capture user credentials.
  • Attackers leveraging push notifications or pop-up messages within compromised apps.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to user accounts and sensitive data such as passwords, financial details, or personal information.
  • Installation of additional malware through fraudulent links or app downloads.
  • Erosion of user trust in mobile communications and associated services.
  • Potential financial loss and privacy breaches resulting from compromised credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile user receives a text message that appears to be from their bank, prompting them to click a link that directs them to a fraudulent website mimicking the banks login page, where their credentials are harvested.
  • An attacker sends a phishing email to a mobile device user containing a link to a cloned version of a popular social media app; once the user logs in, their account details are captured and misused.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Infiltration of malicious applications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries distributing malicious applications that appear legitimate to mobile device users. These apps may be designed to steal sensitive data, deliver malware, or gain unauthorized access to device functions. The infiltration often occurs through unofficial app stores or by disguising malware as a benign application, bypassing traditional security checks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals creating and distributing malicious apps through third-party or compromised official app stores.
  • Attackers leveraging social engineering tactics to convince users to download and install fraudulent applications.
  • Malicious developers embedding harmful code into apps that mimic legitimate functionalities.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in app vetting processes to bypass security filters.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data stored on the mobile device.
  • Installation of additional malware that can further compromise device security.
  • Financial loss due to fraudulent transactions or identity theft.
  • Erosion of user trust in mobile applications and potential reputational damage for affected organizations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A user downloads an application from an unofficial app store that appears to offer useful features but secretly collects personal data and transmits it to a remote server controlled by an attacker.
  • An attacker disguises a malicious app as a popular game, tricking users into installing it; once installed, the app gains access to contacts, messages, and location data, which are then exploited for targeted phishing or identity theft.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1630.001 - Uninstall Malicious Application

threat.name: Exploitation of unpatched mobile OS vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries taking advantage of unpatched or outdated mobile operating system vulnerabilities. Without timely updates, known security flaws remain open to exploitation, allowing attackers to bypass security controls, gain unauthorized access, or execute arbitrary code on the device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals targeting devices running outdated mobile OS versions
  • State-sponsored attackers leveraging known or zero-day vulnerabilities
  • Automated attack tools scanning for vulnerable devices
  • Malicious applications exploiting OS flaws to escalate privileges

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data
  • Complete device compromise, including installation of persistent malware
  • Potential for lateral movement within connected enterprise networks
  • Erosion of user trust and possible regulatory or financial repercussions

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an outdated mobile OS to bypass authentication, gaining root access and installing spyware to monitor user activity.
  • Automated malware targets devices with unpatched operating systems, exploiting the vulnerability to install ransomware that encrypts sensitive data and demands payment for decryption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1455 - Exploit Baseband Vulnerability

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-707
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-707: Improper Neutralization The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.

weakness.name: CWE-923
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-923: Improper Restriction of Communication Channel to Intended Endpoints The product establishes a communication channel to (or from) an endpoint for privileged or protected operations, but it does not properly ensure that it is communicating with the correct endpoint.

countermeasure.name: Implement encryption mechanisms
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard CRM data from interception and unauthorized access, it is crucial to implement robust encryption mechanisms. Follow these steps to ensure data protection:

  • Select an Encryption Algorithm: Choose a strong encryption algorithm such as AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) with a key length of at least 256 bits for maximum security.
  • Encrypt Data at Rest: Ensure all stored CRM data, including databases and backups, are encrypted. This can be accomplished by using built-in encryption features of database systems or third-party encryption tools.
  • Encrypt Data in Transit: Use protocols like TLS (Transport Layer Security) to encrypt data as it moves between CRM systems and users or other systems. Validate the use of up-to-date cipher suites for secure communication.
  • Key Management: Implement a secure key management process. This includes generating, storing, rotating, and revoking encryption keys securely. Consider using hardware security modules (HSMs) for enhanced protection.
  • Access Control: Restrict access to encryption keys and encrypted data to authorized personnel only. Implement role-based access controls and regularly review access permissions.
  • Regular Audits: Conduct regular security audits and testing to ensure the encryption mechanisms remain effective and compliant with industry standards or legal requirements.
  • Update Cryptographic Libraries: Keep all cryptographic libraries and protocols up to date to protect against vulnerabilities that could compromise encryption integrity.

By adhering to these guidelines, your CRM data will be fortified against unauthorized access and interceptions, enhancing the overall security posture of your organization's customer data management.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Implement MDM protection
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively safeguard sensitive data within CRM mobile devices, it is crucial to implement a robust Mobile Device Management (MDM) solution. This can be achieved by following a structured approach:

  1. Evaluate and Select MDM Solution: Identify a suitable MDM provider that aligns with your organization's security requirements and supports the CRM platform.
  2. Develop an MDM Policy: Create a comprehensive policy outlining acceptable use, security protocols, and privacy considerations for mobile devices accessing the CRM.
  3. Enroll Devices: Deploy the MDM software across all CRM-related mobile devices. Ensure that each device is registered and compliant with the established security policies.
  4. Configure Security Settings:
    • Enable encryption and enforce strong authentication methods such as biometrics or multi-factor authentication.
    • Set password policies, including complexity and expiration requirements.
    • Limit data sharing and block installation of unauthorized apps.
  5. Regular Monitoring and Auditing: Set up monitoring tools to track device compliance and perform regular security audits to ensure adherence to policies.
  6. Incident Response Plan: Develop a protocol to address any security incidents or breaches involving mobile devices swiftly, minimizing data exposure risk.

By implementing these measures, you will enhance the protection of sensitive data embedded within CRM mobile devices, ensuring compliance with security standards and reducing potential vulnerabilities.

standard.ref: AC-14 PERMITTED ACTIONS WITHOUT IDENTIFICATION OR AUTHENTICATION
AC-19 Access Control for Mobile Devices
DE.CM-3: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
Requests to Limit Use and Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information (m)(2)
SC-2 Separation of System and User Functionality
