AC-19 Access Control for Mobile Devices

countermeasure.name: Install trusted antivirus
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard CRM data from viruses, worms, and trojans, it is crucial to install a trusted anti-virus program. This countermeasure involves several key steps:

  1. Select a Trusted Anti-Virus Program: Begin by evaluating and selecting a well-known and trusted anti-virus solution that is regularly updated to combat the latest threats. Look for programs that specifically mention capabilities for protecting business applications and data.
  2. Plan the Installation: Create a deployment plan that includes a list of all devices and servers within the CRM environment that require protection. Ensure that the anti-virus program will not interfere with CRM operations.
  3. Install the Anti-Virus Software: Deploy the chosen anti-virus software across all identified systems. Follow the vendor's guidelines for installation to ensure full functionality. If possible, implement the anti-virus solution using a centralized management system to streamline the process.
  4. Configure Regular Scans: Set up the anti-virus program to perform regular scans of the CRM system and associated data. Determine the appropriate frequency to balance thoroughness and system performance.
  5. Enable Real-Time Protection: Ensure that real-time protection features are enabled so that the anti-virus software continuously monitors and defends against threats as they occur.
  6. Update and Patch Management: Schedule automatic updates for the anti-virus program to ensure it has the latest virus definitions and security patches. Confirm that updates do not disrupt CRM operations.
  7. Monitor and Review Alerts: Regularly monitor the anti-virus softwares alerts and logs for any detected threats. Investigate any findings promptly to ensure swift remediation.
  8. Conduct Training: Educate stakeholders on the importance of the anti-virus software and ensure that staff understand how to identify and report potential threats or false positives.
  9. Regularly Review Effectiveness: Periodically review the effectiveness of the chosen anti-virus program. Make adjustments as necessary, based on emerging threats and changes in the CRM environment.

Implementing these measures not only helps protect CRM data from malicious attacks but also maintains the overall integrity and reliability of the system.

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools
SA-8 Security and Privacy Engineering Principles

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data embedded in the system
threat.desc:
General threat description
An unauthorized entity explores a specific CRM platform aiming to locate and potentially expose confidential information that has been integrated into the system.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals or malicious insiders who have gained access to the CRM environment and use tools or exploits to identify and extract sensitive data.
Impacts
Disclosure of sensitive customer data, loss of customer trust, potential legal ramifications, and financial damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An external attacker breaches the CRM system's security defenses and systematically mines embedded sensitive information, such as personal customer details or proprietary business data, leading to data breaches or financial fraud.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

threat.name: Man-in-the-middle attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could intercept the communication between the client and the CRM server, allowing them unauthorized access to sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors or hackers who use man-in-the-middle tactics to compromise network security and insert themselves into the communication channel.
Impacts
Compromised confidentiality and integrity of CRM data, leading to potential data theft, manipulation, and loss of customer trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker sets up a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot in a public area where employees connect to manage CRM data, intercepting and capturing sensitive information exchanged between user devices and the CRM system.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Malicious file upload
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers may gain access to sensitive information or take over CRM systems by uploading harmful files, potentially exploiting system vulnerabilities or improper validation checks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external attackers or malicious insiders. They can leverage file upload functionalities in the CRM system to execute their attack by bypassing security controls or exploiting software flaws.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, loss of customer trust, potential financial losses, and disruption of business operations as the attackers can manipulate, steal, or destroy vital CRM data.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may upload a specially crafted file that, when processed by the CRM system, executes hidden scripts leading to unauthorized access. For instance, a pseudo-image file containing embedded malware script bypasses weak validation mechanisms, allowing the attacker to execute commands remotely to access confidential information stored within the CRM.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

countermeasure.name: Enable 2FA in social media
countermeasure.desc:
2-step verification (often shortened to 2SV and sometimes called two-factor authentication) provides a way of 'double checking' that you really are the person you are claiming to be when you're using social media. Even if a criminal (or someone simply looking to cause mischief) knows your password, they won't be able to access any of your accounts that are protected using 2SV.

Remediation:
Some methods of the 2FA are:
- Push notifications
- SMS notifications
- Email notifications

We advise you to refer to the documentation specific to each social media you use to find how to enable 2FA/MF authentication.

Reference:

  • Social Media: how to use it safely

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Use privacy settings for social media
countermeasure.desc:
Making use of the site's privacy and security settings, helps users to control who can see their profiles, posts and photos and other personal information.

Remediation:
Learn about and use the privacy and security settings on your social networking sites. Configure these settings according to your comfort level (or business level if needed), keeping in mind what your followers and friends need to know, and what detail is unnecessary (but could be useful for attackers).

References:

  • Best Practices: Safe Social Networking
  • Social Media: how to use it safely

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1036 - Account Use Policies

countermeasure.name: Use strong passwords for social media
countermeasure.desc:
Passwords used either as a sole verification credentials, or as part of a multi-factor authentication, are a key aspect of application security, and strong password selection should be encouraged.
Having a strong combination of credentials can prevent unauthorized users from finding these credentials and gaining access to social media accounts.

Remediation:
1. Use a non-common username and that doesn't help identify you, such as maryjsmith_1961.

2. The password length must be at least 12 characters.

3. The complexity of the password is important. Use at least one digit, one lower-case character, one upper-case character, and one special character.

4. Use a different password for each of your social media accounts.

5. Set up your security answers. This option is available for most social media sites.

6. If you have social media apps on your phone, be sure to password protect your device.

Reference:

  • Social Media: how to use it safely

standard.ref: AC-14 PERMITTED ACTIONS WITHOUT IDENTIFICATION OR AUTHENTICATION
AC-19 Access Control for Mobile Devices
DE.CM-3: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
Requests to Limit Use and Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information (m)(2)
SC-2 Separation of System and User Functionality

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1036 - Account Use Policies

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Privacy vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Improperly configured privacy settings on social media can expose personal and sensitive information to unauthorized users or the public. These privacy vulnerabilities can lead to misuse of personal data, identity theft, or unauthorized profiling by malicious actors or third parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents external attackers, data brokers, unauthorized users
  • Attack Vectors lack of restricted access controls, default public settings, oversharing personal information

Impacts

  • Data Exposure personal information becomes accessible to unauthorized individuals, increasing the risk of data misuse
  • Identity Theft exposed data can be used by attackers for impersonation or social engineering
  • Targeted Exploitation attackers may use exposed information to conduct phishing attacks, scams, or unwanted surveillance

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Profile Exposure a users profile is set to public by default, allowing anyone to view their personal details, location, and connections, which can be exploited for phishing attacks.
  2. Data Aggregation third-party data brokers collect exposed profile information to create detailed user profiles, potentially infringing on user privacy.
  3. Social Engineering attackers use publicly visible information, such as family details or employment history, to craft convincing phishing or scam messages targeting the user.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1082 - System Information Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate authentication controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Weak or insufficient authentication controls on social media accounts increase the risk of unauthorized access. Without robust authentication measures, attackers can compromise accounts, gaining access to personal data and the ability to impersonate users, leading to data breaches and potential misuse of the account.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents external attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA), weak password policies, reliance on single-factor authentication

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access attackers may gain control of accounts, leading to data exposure or reputational damage
  • Impersonation Risks compromised accounts can be used for phishing, fraud, or to spread misinformation
  • Data Breach personal or sensitive information accessible through the account may be leaked or manipulated

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Brute-Force Attack attackers use automated tools to guess weak passwords and gain access to a social media account.
  2. Credential Stuffing attackers use leaked credentials from other platforms to access social media accounts lacking multi-factor authentication.
  3. Phishing Attack users are tricked into providing login credentials, allowing attackers to take control of their accounts.

threat.name: Weak passwords
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Weak or easily guessable passwords on social media accounts make it easier for attackers to gain unauthorized access through brute-force attacks or simple password guessing. Weak passwords undermine account security, increasing the risk of data exposure, impersonation, and unauthorized account activities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents external attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors brute-force attacks, credential stuffing, password reuse across platforms, commonly used or simple passwords

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access attackers can compromise accounts, leading to loss of control over personal data and communications
  • Identity Theft attackers can impersonate the user, misusing the account for scams or phishing
  • Data Breach sensitive information in the account may be exposed, leading to privacy risks and potential data misuse

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Brute-Force Attack an attacker uses automated tools to repeatedly guess weak passwords like "123456" or "password," eventually gaining access to the account.
  2. Credential Reuse a user reuses the same weak password across multiple platforms; attackers use credentials from a breached site to access the social media account.
  3. Password Guessing an attacker successfully guesses a users simple or commonly used password, gaining unauthorized access to the account.
